An AiM camera is affixed to the top of the dash, and additional equipment includes a Motorola radio, a Cool Shirt system, and an OMP racing seat with a racing harness.

An Alcantara-wrapped steering wheel with an integrated gear indicator and shift lights frames a 160-mph speedometer and a tachometer with a 7k-rpm redline. The digital odometer indicates 10k miles, all of which were added under current ownership.

The replacement turbocharged 3.0-liter N55 inline-six was installed in March 2019, and the turbocharger was replaced that May. Additional service performed in June 2020 included replacing the DME, water pump, and primary radiator and installing an M4-specification auxiliary radiator.

Power is sent to the rear wheels through a paddle-shifted ZF eight-speed automatic transmission as well as a replacement limited-slip differential that was installed in April 2021. A replacement transmission cooler was fitted in July 2020.

The seller has reportedly won nine WRL races in the GTO class with the car, including the 2018 championship race. It is also said to have notched eight first-place finishes at SCCA Hoosier Super Tour events as well as second place at the 2020 SCCA runoffs.
The Carfax report is free of accidents or other reported damage.

This 1966 Ferrari 330 GT 2+2 is one of approximately 460 Series II examples produced between 1965 and 1967 and was completed around August 1966. Chassis 8845 is said to have been purchased and placed in storage by its second owner in 1971 before being sold to the selling dealer in 2013. Subsequent work included a repaint in silver, replacement of the exhaust system, and a rebuild of the servo-assisted disc brakes. Power is provided by a 4.0-liter Colombo V12 that breathes through triple Weber carburetors and is mated to a five-speed manual transmission. Additional features include a limited-slip differential, servo-assisted four-wheel disc brakes, coil-spring suspension with Koni shock absorbers, 15” Campagnolo center-lock wheels, red leather upholstery, and power windows. This 330 GT 2+2 is now offered by the selling dealer at no reserve with invoices from current ownership, a tool kit, and a clean California title.

The 330 GT was designed as a longer-wheelbase successor to the 330 America and debuted at the Brussels Motor Show in January 1964 with Pininfarina styling featuring a rounded rear profile with wraparound taillight assemblies and a quad-headlight front fascia. Revisions for the model’s second series in 1965 included single headlights, three-louver fender vents, and bumpers with rubber-lined overriders.

This example was stripped to bare metal and repainted in silver during a refresh performed between 2017 and 2021, which also included metalwork on various panels. The front bumpers and overriders were replaced during the project, as were various glass and body seals. Features include a Talbot driver-side mirror, front and rear quarter vent windows, and quad ANSA exhaust outlets.

The Campagnolo wheels were media-blasted and powder-coated in silver during the refresh, at which time 205VR15 Pirelli Cinturato tires were mounted. Stopping is handled by servo-assisted disc brakes with a dual-circuit master cylinder and a single Dunlop booster. Work performed under current ownership included rebuilds of the calipers, turning of the rotors, and replacement of the master cylinder and hoses.

The cabin is trimmed in red leather over the 2+2 seating as well as over the door panels and console, while contrasting black upholstery covers the dash and door caps. Additional features include red carpeting, color-keyed lap belts, a Pininfarina-branded ashtray, a wood dash fascia hosting a lockable glovebox, and power windows.

The wood-rimmed steering wheel sits ahead of Veglia instrumentation including a 300-km/h speedometer, an 8k-rpm tachometer, and gauges monitoring oil temperature and oil pressure. The five-digit odometer shows 34k kilometers (~21k miles), less than 1k of which have been added under current ownership. A quartet of instruments to the driver’s right includes a clock and gauges monitoring coolant temperature, amperage, and fuel level.

The 4.0-liter Colombo Tipo 209 V12 breathes through triple Weber carburetors and was factory rated at 300 horsepower. The carburetors were cleaned and synced during the refresh under current ownership.

Power is sent to the rear wheels via an all-synchromesh five-speed manual transmission and a limited-slip differential. Suspension incorporates an independent front setup and a leaf-sprung solid-axle rear end, with coil springs and Koni telescopic shock absorbers at all four corners.
There is currently a lien on the car, and the owner’s lender will need to be paid off before the title can be transferred to the new owner.

This 1985 Ferrari Testarossa was delivered new in Germany and modified by Koenig Specials in 1986 with their Competition Evolution II conversion, which included installation of revised bodywork along with a KCE 1000 Turbotronic twin-turbo kit. The car subsequently spent time with a second owner in Germany prior to being relocated to Japan, where it remained with its third owner until 2009 before being acquired by the selling dealer’s client and brought to the US in 2023. The modified Koenig Specials bodywork incorporates updated fascias, vented fenders, side air intakes, and a raised rear wing along with fixed headlights, louvered taillights, and a plexiglass engine cover. Inside, power-adjustable bucket seats trimmed in red leather are accompanied by Schroth four-point harnesses along with a MOMO steering wheel, Koenig-branded instrumentation, a boost-control dial, and a custom stereo. The 4.9L F113A flat-12 is fitted with twin KKK turbochargers, side-mounted intercoolers, a MoTeC engine management system, and a center-exit exhaust system. Shifting is through a five-speed manual transaxle with a limited-slip differential, and further equipment includes Koni shocks, H&R springs, AP Racing disc brakes, and 17″ multi-piece alloy wheels. A timing belt service is said to have been performed in preparation for the sale, and the car now shows 17k kilometers (~11k miles). This Koenig Specials–modified Testarossa is offered on dealer consignment in California with a clean Montana title.

Koenig Specials is a German tuning company that was founded by privateer racer Willy König in 1977 in Munich, West Germany. The company began by modifying contemporary Ferrari Berlinetta Boxer models before turning their attention to the Testarossa upon its release in 1984. Following the debut of a Koenig Specials–modified Testarossa at the 1985 Frankfurt Motor Show, the company would go on to offer various upgrade packages for the car including their Competition, Competition Cabrio, and Competition Evolution conversions.

A later Competition Evolution II example, this car is finished in red and features revised fascias, vented fenders, side air intakes, a plexiglass engine cover, and a raised rear wing. Fixed headlights are paired with louvered taillights, and dual polished central exhaust outlets exit from the bodywork at the rear. A Koenig Specials decal is affixed to the windshield, while Koenig Turbo graphics appear ahead of the rear wheels.

The 17″ multi-piece wheels feature gold centers and are mounted with 235/45 Michelin Pilot Sport 4 tires up front and 335/35 Pirelli P-Zero Asimmetrico rubber out back. The car rides on Koni shocks fitted with H&R springs, and braking is handled by AP Racing calipers over two-piece slotted rotors at all four corners.

The power-adjustable bucket seats are trimmed in red leather, which extends to the dash, center console, and doors. The seats are accompanied by Koenig-branded Schroth four-point harnesses as well as retractable three-point seatbelts. A Sony AM/FM cassette stereo is connected to Quart speakers, and further appointments include a digital clock, a defroster, and power windows.

The leather-wrapped MOMO steering wheel is paired with a gated dogleg shifter and frames Koenig-branded instrumentation including a 360-km/h speedometer and a 10k-rpm tachometer flanked by oil and boost pressure gauges. A MoTec C125 digital display is located atop the center stack, which also houses a six-digit Veglia Borletti mechanical odometer that indicates 17k kilometers (~11k miles).
A boost-control dial on the dash allows the driver to select between various power-output levels.

The mid-mounted 4.9L F113A flat-12 was fitted with a Koenig Specials KCE 1000 Turbotronic kit in 1986, according to the selling dealer. Koenig Specials rated the engine for 1,000PS in Evolution trim. The engine is equipped with twin KKK turbochargers, side-mounted intercoolers, oil coolers, Turbosmart external wastegates, a MoTeC engine management system, and a modified center-exit exhaust system.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through a five-speed manual transaxle and a limited-slip differential.
The Carfax report is free of accidents or other reported damage from a single entry in April 2024.

attributes.value: Testarossa Koenig Specials Competition Evolution II

description: This 1999 Ferrari 550 Maranello shows 4,400 miles, and it was specified in Blu Tour de France over Grigio Scuro leather. It is powered by a 5.5-liter V12 paired with a six-speed manual transaxle, and equipment includes a limited-slip differential, 18″ five-spoke alloy wheels, fog lights, power-adjustable seats, a gated shifter, a remote CD changer, and automatic climate control. Service in August 2023 included replacing the battery, tires, and upper radiator hoses. This 550 Maranello is now offered in Colorado by the selling dealer with a clean Carfax report and a clean Montana title.

The 550 Maranello was styled by Pininfarina, and this example is finished in Blu Tour de France. Equipment includes projector-style headlights, fog lights, a hood scoop, a front spoiler, front fender vents, and quad exhaust tips exiting through the rear bumper cover. A paint-correction was performed and a ceramic coating was applied to the body in August 2023, at which time a clear paint-protection film was applied to the front.
The photos were taken in September 2023.

The 18″ five-spoke alloy wheels reportedly received a ceramic coating in August 2023, and the Michelin Pilot Super Sport tires were mounted at that time. Braking is handled by black-finished Ferrari-branded calipers over cross-drilled and ventilated rotors at all four corners. Additional work in August 2023 included flushing the brake fluid.

The cabin features power-adjustable seats upholstered in Grigio Scuro leather. Amenities include a gated shifter, automatic climate control, electric windows, a cassette stereo, a remote CD changer, a hi-fi sound system, and rear luggage straps. The sticky surfaces and cracked buttons were addressed in March 2020.

The leather-wrapped three-spoke steering wheel fronts a Jaeger gauge cluster with a 220-mph speedometer and a tachometer with a 7,600-rpm redline as well as gauges for coolant temperature and oil pressure, while an analog clock and gauges for oil temperature and fuel level are located atop the center stack. The six-digit odometer shows 4,400 miles.

The 5.5-liter quad-cam F133A V12 features 48 valves, dry-sump lubrication, and Bosch Motronic engine management for a factory-rated output of 478 horsepower and 419 lb-ft of torque. The most recent belt service was performed in November 2020, and work in August 2023 included replacing the battery and upper radiator hoses.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through a six-speed manual transaxle and a limited-slip differential.
The Carfax report shows is free of accidents or other reported damage.

This 1954 Citroën 11BL is said to have remained with the family of its original owner until the current owner’s acquisition in 2012 following several decades of storage. Subsequent refurbishment work involved stripping the body to bare metal and repainting it in black, reupholstering the interior, and rebuilding the 1.9-liter inline-four and three-speed manual transaxle. Equipment includes metric steel wheels, rack-and-pinion steering, torsion-bar suspension, and front-wheel-drive with homokinetic drive axles. This Traction Avant is now offered on dealer consignment in New Hampshire with refurbishment records, manufacturer’s literature, and a clean California title.

The car was dismantled and the steel unibody was stripped to bare metal before a repaint in black during the aforementioned refurbishment. Exterior details include a louvered hood, a tilt-out windshield, coach front doors, and aluminum stone guards. Paint imperfections are displayed in the video below.

Cream-finished 400mm steel wheels have chrome center caps and are mounted with 165-series Michelin X tires. The torsion-bar suspension features independent front wishbones and rear trailing arms linked to a beam axle and a panhard bar. The car is equipped with rack-and-pinion steering, and braking is handled by four-wheel drums that were overhauled in 2013.

Sound-deadening material was added to the cabin floors and inner doors before the interior was retrimmed in gray vinyl and cloth. Laps belts are provided for front occupants, and holes in the headliner are shown up close in the gallery.

The two-spoke steering wheel fronts a 150-km/h Jaeger speedometer with an inset fuel gauge and ammeter, while metric gauges for oil pressure and coolant temperature have been added on the left side of the dashboard. The five-digit odometer shows 2,100 kilometers (~1,300 miles), which is said to represent the distance added since completion of the refurbishment. Total mileage is unknown.

The 1.9-liter inline-four is mounted longitudinally behind the transaxle and features a single Solex carburetor. The engine was rebuilt in 2013, and the battery was replaced in preparation for the sale.

Power is sent to the front wheels through a three-speed manual transaxle. Replacement drive axles with homokinetic outer joints were installed during the refurbishment along with a diaphragm-style clutch pressure plate.
Photos taken at various stages of the refurbishment are presented in the gallery.

This 2005 Ferrari 612 Scaglietti is powered by a 5.7-liter V12 paired with a six-speed transaxle that was converted to manual operation in October 2023. Finished in Blu Mirabeau over Beige Tradizione leather upholstery, it is equipped with 18″ and 19″ five-spoke alloy wheels, xenon headlights, a gated shifter, heated and power-adjustable front seats, a CD stereo, and dual-zone automatic climate control. Additional work at the time of the gearbox conversion included changing the oil and coolant, installing H&R sway bars, and servicing the air-conditioning system along with repairing sticky interior buttons and replacing the timing and serpentine belts, clutch, engine and transmission mounts, battery, and more as detailed below. Following registration history in California, New Jersey, and New York, the vehicle was acquired by the selling dealer in June 2024. With 18k miles, this 612 Scaglietti is now offered with owner’s manuals, a tool and spares kit, service records, a clean Carfax report, and a clean Pennsylvania title.

The Pininfarina-designed 612 Scaglietti was the first V12-powered Ferrari to move from steel to aluminum-intensive construction. This example is finished in Blu Mirabeau and features xenon headlights, heated side mirrors, rear parking sensors, and quad exhaust outlets. The panel under the left-side exhaust outlets was repaired in 2023.

Five-spoke alloy wheels measuring 18″ up front and 19″ out back are mounted with 245/45 and 285/40 Pirelli P Zero tires, respectively. Braking is handled by black-finished calipers over cross-drilled and ventilated rotors. H&R sway bars have been added, and the steering-rack boots and power-steering hoses were replaced in October 2023.

The heated and power-adjustable front seats are upholstered in Beige Tradizione leather with Cavallino Rampante headrest embossments, and the lower dashboard, center console, door panels, and individual rear seats are trimmed to match. Additional appointments include a gated shifter, a factory CD stereo, drilled aluminum pedals, front-seat position memory, and dual-zone automatic climate control. Work in October 2023 included repairing sticky interior buttons, evacuating and recharging the air-conditioning system, and replacing the leather headliner and the battery-cover panel.

The replacement power-adjustable, leather-wrapped steering wheel frames instrumentation consisting of a 220-mph speedometer, a central 10k-rpm tachometer, and a configurable digital display. The digital odometer indicates 18k miles, approximately 300 of which were added under current ownership.

The 5.7-liter DOHC V12 was factory rated at 533 horsepower and 434 lb-ft of torque. A replacement timing-belt kit was installed in October 2023, and additional work at that time included changing the oil, flushing the coolant, and replacing the following:

Power is sent to the rear wheels via a six-speed transaxle, which was converted to manual operation in October 2023 at European Auto Group of Austin, Texas. The clutch and thrust bearing were replaced at that time, and the rear transmission cover was resealed.
The window sticker lists initial delivery to Ferrari San Francisco in California, factory colors and equipment, and a total suggested retail price of $269,697.
The Carfax report is free of accident or damage entries and it notes an open manufacturer recall from September 2022.

This 2018 McLaren 720S Performance coupe was purchased new by the owner at McLaren Chicago and it now has 706 miles. Finished in Cosmos over Scoria Grey leather and Alcantara upholstery, the car is powered by a twin-turbocharged 4.0-liter V8 mated to a seven-speed dual-clutch transaxle. Optional equipment includes the Carbon Fiber Exterior Upgrade Pack 2 and 3 as well as the Stealth Pack, Super-Lightweight forged wheels, a sports exhaust system, carbon fiber visible body structure, a vehicle-lift system, 360-degree park assist, McLaren Track Telemetry, heated and power-adjustable seats, electric heated memory mirrors, and a 12-speaker audio system. This 720S Launch Edition is now offered on dealer consignment with McLaren luggage, a car cover, window stickers, a clean Carfax report, and a clean Indiana title.

The 720S utilizes a carbon-fiber Monocage II monocoque with an extruded aluminum subframe. This example is finished in Cosmos black. The car was optioned with the Stealth Pack as well as a visible carbon-fiber body structure and Carbon Fiber Exterior Upgrade Packs 2 and 3. Further exterior details include twin-hinge dihedral soft-close doors, a 360-degree park assist system, dual exhaust outlets exiting through the rear fascia, and an active rear spoiler with an air brake and an automatic Drag Reduction System.

Optional Super-Lightweight 19″ and 20″ forged wheels are finished in Titanium Liquid Metal and mounted with 245/35 front and 305/30 rear Pirelli P Zero Trofeo R tires. The three-mode adaptive suspension features double wishbones at all four corners, and the car is equipped with a vehicle lift system. Stopping power is provided by carbon-ceramic rotors and Azores-finished calipers. The suspension accumulators were replaced in preparation for the sale.

The bucket seats are upholstered in Scoria Grey Alcantara and leather upholstery that extends to the dashboard and door panels. A Launch Edition plaque is affixed to the driver-side door sill, and additional equipment includes the Carbon Fiber Secondary Interior Components package, dual-zone automatic climate control, a 12-speaker audio system, and a touchscreen infotainment system with navigation.

The carbon-fiber and Alcantara-wrapped steering wheel features paddle shifters and is mounted ahead of instrumentation consisting of a folding LCD screen that displays a speedometer, tachometer, trip functions, and vehicle information. The digital odometer indicates 706 miles.

The twin-turbocharged 4.0-liter M840T V8 utilizes a flat-plane crankshaft as well as dry-sump lubrication and was factory rated at 710 horsepower and 568 lb-ft of torque. An oil change was performed in preparation for the sale.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through a seven-speed dual-clutch Seamless Shift transaxle, and the car is equipped with an optional sports exhaust system.
Two window stickers are included in the sale and show initial delivery to McLaren Chicago in Illinois, and list factory colors, equipment, and a total suggested retail price of $367,195.
A set of McLaren-branded luggage and a car cover will accompany the vehicle.
The Carfax report is free of accidents or other reported damage.
listing_details: Carbon Fiber Primary & Secondary Interior Components Packages

description: This 1963 Jaguar XKE Series I coupe was repainted green and fitted with a replacement 4.2-liter inline-six under prior ownership. The car was purchased by the current owner after it was listed on BaT in January 2022, and subsequent refurbishment work has included interior repairs, rear suspension and fuel-system overhauls, a rebuild of the clutch master cylinder, and installation of a RetroSound stereo, an aluminum radiator, and triple SU carburetors. The car also has four-wheel disc brakes, chrome 15″ knock-off wire wheels, GAZ adjustable shocks, glass headlight covers, and a stainless-steel dual exhaust system. This Series I XKE is now offered on dealer consignment with a Jaguar Heritage Trust Certificate copy, service records, spare parts, and a clean Michigan title.

The body was repainted in green during previous ownership, and exterior features include split chrome bumpers, triple windshield wipers, glass headlight covers, and dual exhaust outlets. There are paint and chrome blemishes noted in close-up photos provided in the gallery below.

Dayton chrome 15″ knock-off wire wheels are mounted with 185-section Vredestein Sprint Classic tires, and adjustable GAZ shocks have been installed. The car is equipped with four-wheel disc brakes, and service in 2023 included repairing the rear suspension mounting points and replacing the inner tie rods as well as the shock-absorber and pivot-rod bushings.

The cabin is trimmed in green and features textured aluminum trim on the dashboard and center console. The low-back bucket seats wear replacement leather covers and lap belts with Jaguar logos. The door panels, center console upholstery, and carpet padding were replaced in 2023 and a Bluetooth-capable RetroSound stereo was installed.

The wood-rim steering wheel frames Smiths instrumentation including a 160-mph speedometer and a 6k-rpm tachometer with an inset clock. The five-digit odometer shows 32k miles, under 300 of which were added under current ownership. True mileage is unknown.

The 4.2-liter inline-six was installed during previous ownership and was fitted with triple SU carburetors in 2023. A Howe aluminum radiator was also installed under current ownership, and the fuel pump, fuel tank, and fuel lines were repaired.

Power is sent to the rear wheels through a four-speed manual transmission. The clutch master cylinder was rebuilt and the differential seals were replaced in 2023, and the car has a stainless-steel ClassicFabs exhaust system.
Images showing various stages of the work performed following the current owner’s acquisition are presented in the gallery.
A reproduction chassis tag has been installed, and the frame has been re-stamped.
A copy of the Jaguar Heritage Trust certificate displays factory colors and equipment as well as a manufacture date in March 1962. The certificate notes that the body and chassis number do not align.

This 1948 Willys-Overland Jeepster was acquired by the current owner in 1992 and subsequently refurbished by Suburban Rod and Custom Classics in Missouri. The truck was refinished in red over black and a 134ci F-head inline-four was installed. Equipment includes a three-speed manual transmission, overdrive, a retractable soft top, a 12-volt electrical system, 15″ wheels, chrome brightwork, an AM radio, and a Mustang II-sourced independent front suspension with disc brakes. This Jeepster is now offered at no reserve by the seller on behalf of the owner with a clean California title.

The truck was refinished in red by Suburban Rod, and it is equipped with a replacement black soft top with red accents. The seller reports that the brightwork was replated during the build and that steel replacement panels were used.

Body-color 15″ steel wheels wear polished covers and are mounted with BFGoodrich whitewall tires. Independent front suspension components from a Mustang II have reportedly been installed, and stopping power is provided by front discs and rear drums.

The cabin features bench seats upholstered in replacement black vinyl with red piping. Metal surfaces are finished in the color of the body, and equipment includes a column-mounted shifter, an AM radio, a split-folding front bench, black door panel inserts, and black carpets with red trim.

An ivory-color steering wheel fronts a central instrument cluster consisting of an 80-mph speedometer and gauges for fuel level, amperage, oil pressure, and coolant temperature. An aftermarket oil pressure gauge is located below the dashboard. The five-digit odometer shows 2k miles, a handful of which were added under current ownership. True mileage is unknown.

A 134ci F-head inline-four has been installed and it sends power to the rear wheels through a three-speed manual transmission with overdrive. The truck’s electrical system was also converted to 12 volts during the build.
Per the seller, the clutch was replaced in 2023. Additional underside photos are provided in the gallery.

This ’32 Ford hot rod is a fiberglass-bodied roadster that is powered by a 350ci Chevy V8 linked to a TH350 three-speed automatic transmission. The engine features aluminum cylinder heads, a COMP camshaft, and a Holley electronic fuel injection system. Finished in black over tan upholstery, the car rides on a custom-fabricated frame equipped with a dropped front axle, four-link rear suspension, and front disc brakes. Other highlights of the build include a louvered steel hood, Sid Chavers BopTop, Dolphin white-dial instrumentation, Unisteer rack-and-pinion steering, 15” and 16” wire wheels, and a Ford 9” rear end with a limited-slip differential. Acquired by the current owner in 2020, this Deuce highboy is now offered on dealer consignment with a clean Wyoming title that describes the car as a 1932 Ford.

The fiberglass body and tubular steel frame were sourced from Kilbourne Rod Shop, and a steel hood and grille shell were added. The exterior is finished in black with tan pinstriping, and other details include a removable Sid Chavers BopTop, a chopped windshield, teardrop taillights, and chrome spreader bars.

Wheelsmith 15” front and 16” rear wire wheels wear polished hubcaps and are mounted with 185/65 and 285/60 BFGoodrich tires, respectively. The suspension features a dropped front axle with a transverse leaf spring, while the solid rear axle is located via a four-link setup and equipped with adjustable coilovers. Unisteer rack-and-pinion steering has been installed, and braking is handled by front discs and rear drums.

The cabin features a bench seat trimmed in beige vinyl upholstery with color-coordinated door panels. Pinstriping accents the body-color dashboard, and additional appointments include a heater, black carpets, and lap belts.

A banjo-style steering wheel is mounted to a tilting column and sits ahead of an AutoMeter 8k-rpm tachometer, while an engine-turned bezel houses Dolphin white-dial instrumentation consisting of a 140-mph speedometer and auxiliary gauges. The six-digit odometer shows 12k miles, approximately 1k of which have been added under current ownership.

The 350ci Chevy V8 is equipped with aluminum Edelbrock cylinder heads, a COMP camshaft, a Holley Sniper electronic fuel injection system, and an MSD distributor. Short-tube exhaust headers flow into a dual exhaust system with Magnaflow mufflers, and a 14-gallon fuel cell is mounted in the trunk along with the battery. The Walker radiator is cooled by a SPAL electric fan.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through a TH350 three-speed automatic transmission and a 9” Ford rear end with a limited-slip differential and 3.55:1 gearing.

This 2000 Ducati 996 was first registered in Massachusetts, and it later spent time in Rhode Island and Quebec, Canada, before it was re-imported to the United States and acquired by the seller in March 2023. Finished in yellow, the bike is powered by a 996cc desmodromic L-twin paired with a six-speed transmission. It also features Marelli fuel injection, a single-sided aluminum swingarm, adjustable suspension, triple disc brakes with Brembo calipers, and five-spoke 17″ Marchesini wheels as well as a clear windscreen, a biposto tail section with a black-upholstered rider seat and a yellow-upholstered passenger seat, and a dual exhaust system with Termignoni carbon-fiber mufflers. This 996 shows 20k miles and is offered with a clean Iowa title in the seller’s name.

The bike wears Massimo Tamburini-designed bodywork and is finished in yellow, and the seller states that several panels were refinished under current ownership. Features include a gray-finished trellis frame, a clear windscreen, a side stand, rear-set foot controls, a biposto tail section with a black-upholstered rider seat and a yellow-upholstered passenger seat, and a side stand in addition to a full fairing that features a clear windscreen, dual mirrors, symmetrical headlights, and DZUS fasteners.

Gray-finished 17″ five-spoke Marchesini wheels wear a Continental tire up front and a Michelin tire out back that bear production date codes from 2013 and 2017, respectively. Adjustable Showa suspension consists of a 43mm inverted fork in addition to a piggyback monoshock connected to the single-sided aluminum swingarm. Braking is from gold-finished Brembo calipers mounted over a pair of drilled rotors up front along with a single Brembo caliper and drilled disc at the rear.

Clip-on handlebars are secured beneath an upper triple clamp that anchors a hydraulic steering damper, which is attached to the right side of the frame. Instrumentation consists of a 180-mph speedometer, a 13k-rpm tachometer, and a coolant temperature gauge. The five-digit odometer shows 20k miles, approximately 100 of which have been ridden by the seller.

The liquid-cooled 996cc L-twin features Marelli fuel injection, four desmodromically actuated valves per cylinder, and a dual exhaust system fitted with a pair of Termignoni carbon-fiber mufflers that exit beneath the tailpiece. The oil was changed under current ownership.
Power is routed to the rear wheel through a multi-plate dry clutch, a six-speed transmission, and a drive chain.
The Iowa title identifies the motorcycle model as a “996 S.”

This 1974 Cadillac Eldorado Convertible was acquired by the selling dealer in 2023 and subsequent work consisted of replacing the white leather upholstery. Power is provided by a 500ci V8 paired with a three-speed automatic transmission, and the car is finished in Cranberry Firemist over white leather upholstery. Equipment includes a power-operated white convertible soft top, power steering, power front disc brakes, power windows, automatic climate control, cruise control, Twilight Sentinel automatic headlights, and a power-adjustable front bench seat as well as 15″ steel wheels with polished covers. This Eldorado Convertible is now offered at no reserve with a clean Arizona title.

The car left the factory in Cranberry Firemist (99) and was repainted under prior ownership. Details include a power-operated white convertible soft top, a two-piece hard parade boot, fender-mounted light monitors, cornering lights, and rear fender skirts. The selling dealer notes that the power-operated top requires manual assistance to raise and lower.

The 15″ steel wheels wear polished covers and are mounted with 235/75 Cooper Trendsetter SE white-stripe tires, that were reportedly installed in 2021. Stopping power is provided by front disc and rear drum brakes. The Eldorado featured a torsion bar front suspension and a coil-sprung solid rear axle along with Automatic Level Control and power steering.

The bench seats were retrimmed in white leather upholstery under current ownership, and the front unit is power-adjustable. Patterned woodgrain trim accents the dash and door panels, and further appointments include automatic climate control, cruise control, a digital clock, Twilight Sentinel automatic headlights, and power windows and door locks.

The three-spoke steering wheel wears a woodgrain cover and frames a 100-mph speedometer and a fuel level gauge. The five-digit odometer shows 66k miles, approximately 1k of which were added by the selling dealer.

The 500ci V8 features a Rochester Quadrajet four-barrel carburetor for a factory output of 210 horsepower and 380 lb-ft of torque. Power is sent to the front wheels through a Turbo Hydra-Matic three-speed automatic transmission.

This 2016 Porsche Cayman GTS is finished in Guards Red over black leather and Alcantara and is powered by a 3.4-liter flat-six paired with a six-speed manual transaxle. Equipment includes the Sport Chrono Package, Porsche Ceramic-Composite Brakes, X73 sport suspension, a short-shift kit, 20″ Carrera S wheels, Porsche Torque Vectoring, an aftermarket rear spoiler, hardback sport seats, and bi-xenon headlights with PDLS. The selling dealer purchased the car in 2021 and has since added approximately 3k of the 27k indicated miles. This 981 Cayman GTS is now offered by the selling dealer with spare parts, two keys, a clean Carfax report, and a clean California title.

This example is finished in Guards Red and equipped with bi-xenon headlights with the Porsche Dynamic Light System (PDLS) as well as an aftermarket rear spoiler, exhaust tips, and front side markers. Other exterior details include side air intakes, auto-dimming mirrors with a rain sensor, and a GTS-specific front fascia, rear diffuser, and tinted taillights. Black vinyl wrap covers the roof and aftermarket spoiler, clear paint protection film covers the nose, and the diffuser has red accents. Photos of paint meter readings are provided in the gallery below. The removed factory spoiler is included in the sale.

Black powder-coated 20″ Carrera S alloy wheels are mounted with titanium lug bolts and Michelin Pilot Sport 4S tires measuring 235/35 up front and 265/35 out back. Braking is handled by four-wheel cross-drilled Porsche Ceramic-Composite Brake (PCCB) discs with yellow-painted Porsche-branded calipers. This example was ordered with X73 sport suspension.

The cockpit features hardback sport seats upholstered in black leather and Alcantara with GT Silver stitching along with Racing Yellow seatbelts. The selling dealer states that a short-shift kit is installed, and other interior appointments include a touchscreen infotainment system, a fire extinguisher mounted in the passenger footwell, and stainless-steel Cayman GTS-branded door sill guards. WeatherTech floor liners are also included in the sale.

The Alcantara-wrapped SportDesign steering wheel frames a Racing Yellow GTS-branded central tachometer with a 7,600-rpm redline as well as a 190-mph speedometer and a digital display. The optional Sport Chrono Package added a stopwatch in the center stack, and this example was ordered with a Racing Yellow dial. The digital odometer indicates 27k miles, approximately 4k of which were added by the selling dealer. The selling dealer notes a warning message on the dashboard for the side markers.
The 3.4-liter flat-six is located behind the passenger compartment and was factory rated at 340 horsepower and 280 lb-ft of torque. A sport exhaust system was equipped from the factory.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through a six-speed manual transaxle with Porsche Torque Vectoring (PTV).
The Carfax report is free of accidents or other reported damage.

This 1995 Mercedes-Benz S320 remained registered in Florida with its original owner until 2024, and it now has 47k miles. The car is powered by a 3.2-liter inline-six paired with a five-speed automatic transmission and is finished in Brilliant Silver Metallic over gray leather upholstery. Equipment includes 16″ Alamak alloy wheels, a sunroof, power-adjustable front seats, dual-zone automatic automatic climate control, and a cassette stereo. Acquired by the selling dealer in 2024, this V140 S320 is offered in North Carolina at no reserve with the manufacturer’s literature and a clean Florida title.

The car is finished in Brilliant Silver Metallic (744), and exterior equipment includes a powered sunroof, double-pane side glass, soft-close doors, a power antenna, and headlight wipers. A June 2017 entry on the Carfax report lists “minor damage” to the rear and left side of the car. Close-up photographs of the exterior finish and trim are shown in the gallery below.

Silver 16″ Alamak alloy wheels are mounted with Michelin tires. The car was factory-equipped with Anti-Slip Regulation (ASR) traction control, and braking is handled by ventilated rotors at each corner.

The seats are upholstered in Gray leather, while Zebrano wood trim accents the cabin. Amenities include power-adjustable front seats with position memory, dual-zone automatic climate control, a cassette stereo, and cruise control.

The leather-wrapped steering wheel frames a 160-mph speedometer, a tachometer, an analog clock, and gauges for oil pressure, coolant temperature, instant fuel economy, and fuel level. The six-digit odometer shows 47k miles.
The 3.2-liter inline-six was factory rated at 228 horsepower and 232 lb-ft of torque.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through a five-speed automatic transmission.
The Carfax report lists the aforementioned June 2017 damage.

This 1969 Kaiser-Jeep M725 is a 1¼-ton ex-military ambulance that is finished in green over green vinyl upholstery and powered by a 230ci inline-six linked to a four-speed manual transmission and a dual-range transfer case. Ambulance-specific equipment includes accommodations for up to five stretchers, a surgical lamp, air ventilators, a gas heater, rear-access steps, and a sliding door between the cab and the rear compartment. The truck also has intake and exhaust snorkels, a grille guard, body-color bumpers, a spotlight, red-cross graphics, green-painted 16″ wheels, and manually locking front hubs. The selling dealer acquired the vehicle in 2023. This M725 is now offered in California at no reserve with a bill of sale.

Produced from 1967 through 1969, the M725 ambulance was based on Kaiser-Jeep’s M715 military truck, which itself was based on the contemporary Jeep Gladiator pickup and offered a 1¼-ton load rating. This example is finished in olive drab green, and a large red-cross graphic spans swing-out rear doors that hold jerrycans. Other features include US Army lettering above the rear doors, body-color bumpers, intake and exhaust snorkels, a grille guard, D rings, dual side mirrors, and a spotlight. A storage compartment is provided ahead of the left-rear wheel.

Green-painted 16″ steel wheels are wrapped with 9.00–16LT Denman military nylon-cord tires that exhibit cracks. Selectro manually locking hubs are found at the front axle. The truck has leaf springs, telescoping shocks, and drum brakes at all four corners.

The cab houses two seats upholstered in green vinyl. An electric fan is mounted above the windshield, a turn-signal controller is attached to the steering column, and the interior also contains a passenger-side grab bar and a glovebox. Discoloration is noted on the passenger seat.

The two-spoke steering wheel fronts central instrumentation including a 60-mph speedometer and gauges for fuel level, water temperature, oil pressure, and voltage. The five-digit odometer shows 2k miles, and true chassis mileage is unknown.

The rear compartment can hold up to five medical stretchers and offers a surgical lamp, air ventilators, a gas heater, and rear-access steps. A sliding door separates the cab from the rear compartment.
The 230.5ci Tornado inline-six features a single-overhead-camshaft design combined with hemispherical combustion chambers. The selling dealer performed a tune-up in preparation for the sale.
Power is delivered to the rear or all four wheels through a four-speed manual transmission and a dual-range transfer case.
The vehicle does not have a title, as it is not intended for road use and has not been registered for the street. It is being offered on a bill of sale.

This 1979 Chevrolet C10 Silverado pickup was converted to four-wheel drive using a replacement chassis under prior ownership and was acquired by the seller’s father in 2016. A 502ci V8 crate engine was subsequently installed, along with Holley Avenger fuel injection, a custom exhaust with ceramic-coated headers and Flowmaster mufflers, and a billet serpentine belt system. The truck was repainted red over black leather upholstery and features a three-speed automatic transmission, a dual-range transfer case, a chrome roll bar with auxiliary lights, a receiver hitch, dual fuel tanks, power steering, 16″ cast-aluminum wheels, a CD stereo, cruise control, and air conditioning. This C10 is now offered by the seller on behalf of their father with records from current ownership and a clean Wyoming title.

The truck is finished in red and was repainted in 2017. Equipment includes a Fleetside bed as well as a roof visor, a chrome roll bar with auxiliary lights, side steps, a receiver hitch, dual fuel tanks, a sliding rear window, and a chrome grille, bumpers, and bed caps. There is rust on the inner corner of the passenger door and in the inner rockers. The seller notes scratches on the tailgate and behind the driver’s door as well as dents and clearcoat peeling in the bed.

The 16″ cast-aluminum wheels are mounted with 315/75 Goodyear Wrangler Duratrac tires. The truck is equipped with power steering and manually locking front hubs. Braking is provided by front discs and rear drums. The seller states the brake master cylinder, tie rod ends, drag links, and ball joints were replaced in 2017.

The cabin features a Wise Guys bench seat upholstered in black leather along with a red dash, carpets, and door panels. Interior appointments include a JVC CD stereo with Bluetooth, cruise control, and air conditioning.

The four-spoke steering wheel frames a 100-mph speedometer and a tachometer along with gauges for fuel level, coolant temperature, oil pressure, and voltage. The five-digit odometer shows 14k miles, approximately 3k of which were added under current ownership. Total mileage is unknown.

The 502ci V8 crate engine was installed in 2017 and features a Holley Avenger fuel injection system as well as Sanderson ceramic-coated headers, an HEI distributor and ignition coil, a Billet Specialties Tru Trac billet serpentine belt system, a Billet Specialties air cleaner, and a custom dual exhaust system with Flowmaster mufflers and an H-pipe. Cooling is through an aluminum radiator with dual fans.

The truck was converted to four-wheel drive under prior ownership using a replacement frame, and power is routed to the rear or all four wheels through a three-speed automatic transmission and an NP203 dual-range transfer case.

This 1975 Ford F-350 Ranger XLT SuperCab Camper Special was acquired by the seller in 2023, and recent work consisted of rebuilding the transmission, retrimming the interior, performing body repairs, installing an exhaust system, and replacing the sound deadening material, exterior and interior lights, belts, and hoses. Power is provided by a 460ci V8 linked with a three-speed automatic transmission and the truck is finished in Glen Green over green vinyl and comfortweave cloth upholstery. Equipment includes the Camper Special package that added heavy-duty shocks and front and rear stabilizer bars and additional features include power steering, power front disc brakes, white 16″ steel wheels, a front-mounted spare tire, a front ball hitch, dual fuel tanks, and a Philco radio. This F-350 Ranger XLT is now offered with a Deluxe Marti report, service records, and a Washington title in the seller’s name.

The truck is finished in Glen Green and features a Styleside bed as well as pinstripes, dual towing mirrors, dual fuel tanks, a chrome front bumper, a front ball hitch, a step rear bumper, and bright bodyside moldings with vinyl inserts. The exterior light bulbs were replaced recently and body repairs have been performed on the right rear quarter panel, left front inner fender, and secondary battery box area. Paint and body blemishes are displayed in the gallery.

White-finished 16″ steel wheels wear bright hubcaps and are mounted with 235/85 Radial SXT All Terrain tires. The truck is equipped with power steering, and braking is provided by power-assisted front discs and rear drums. A full-size spare is mounted to the front bumper.

The split-folding front bench was retrimmed in green vinyl upholstery with comfort weave cloth joined by a color-coordinated rear bench seat, headliner, dashboard pad, and door panels. Amenities include a Philco push-button AM radio, a rubber floor covering, quarter vent windows, opening rear windows, and front lap belts. The sound-deadening material was replaced recently. The air conditioning does not work.

The two-spoke steering wheel frames a 100-mph speedometer as well as gauges for coolant temperature, oil pressure, battery charge status, and fuel level. The dashboard lights were replaced recently. The five-digit odometer shows 27k miles, approximately 500 of which were added under current ownership. Total mileage is unknown.
The 460ci V8 was factory rated at 245 horsepower and recent work consisted of replacing the belts and hoses. There is an oil pan drip according to the seller.

Power is routed to the rear wheels via a three-speed C6 automatic transmission and a 3.73:1 Dana rear axle. The transmission is said to have been rebuilt recently and a replacement exhaust system with a Magnaflow muffler has been fitted.
The Deluxe Marti Report lists factory colors, options, and production statistics. This truck is noted as one of 16 examples produced with the factory options selected.
The Washington title has an Antique brand.

attributes.value: F-350 Ranger XLT SuperCab Camper Special

description: This 1971 Honda Z50A Mini Trail has is said to have remained in Oregon from new through the seller’s 2014 acquisition, reportedly from its second owner. Finished in yellow and white, the bike is powered by a 49cc four-stroke single paired with a three-speed semi-automatic transmission. It also features a Keihin carburetor, a two-position height-adjustable seat, a telescopic fork, trail lighting, drop-down handlebars, chrome fenders, 8″ two-piece wheels, and a side stand. The seller states that the valve clearances were adjusted in preparation for the sale. This Z50A is offered at no reserve with a clean Oregon title in the seller’s name.

The bike is finished in yellow with white accents. Features include a headlight, a taillight, chrome-finished fenders, a two-position height-adjustable black vinyl seat, a 0.7-gallon fuel tank, and a side stand. Chips and scratches are visible on the bodywork and the frame.
Two-piece 8″ steel wheels wear Nitto tires with visible cracks in the sidewalls. Braking is handled by front and rear drums. An inverted fork comprises the bike’s only suspension.

The twist-lock folding handlebars are equipped with a twist-grip throttle and a run switch. The seller estimates having ridden 100 miles under current ownership, though no instrumentation is present, and total mileage is unknown.

The horizontal four-stroke single is equipped with a kick starter, a Keihin carburetor, and an upswept exhaust system with a spark arrestor and slotted chrome heat shields. The seller states that the oil was changed and the valve clearances were adjusted in preparation for the sale.
Power is sent to the rear wheel through a three-speed semi-automatic transmission and a drive chain.

This 2014 Porsche 911 Carrera 4S coupe is a Dark Blue Metallic-finished example that was initially purchased by the owner’s uncle at Napleton Westmont Porsche in Illinois, prior to being acquired by the owner in 2022. Powered by a 3.8-liter flat-six that drives all four wheels through a seven-speed PDK dual-clutch transaxle, the car has Espresso and Cognac leather, the Sport Chrono Package, 20″ Carrera Classic alloy wheels, a sport exhaust system, a limited-slip differential with Porsche Torque Vectoring, a sunroof, LED headlights with PDLS+, Power Steering Plus, heated and ventilated power-adjustable sport front seats, adaptive cruise control with Porsche Active Safe, a Bose sound system, and a heated steering wheel. This 991.1 C4S coupe has 99k miles and is now offered on dealer consignment with service records, a clean Carfax report, and a clean Minnesota title.

The car is finished in Dark Blue Metallic and has LED headlights with Porsche Dynamic Light System Plus (PDLS+) as well as a power sunroof, LED taillights, clear side markers, quad exhaust outlets, a rear window wiper, front and rear parking sensors, and a speed-activated rear spoiler. The front bumper cover has scratches, and paint meter readings are provided in the gallery. Replacement horns were installed in July 2023.

The 20″ Carrera Classic alloy wheels are mounted with Michelin Pilot Sport 4s tires measuring 245/35 up front and 305/30 at the rear. Braking is handled by red-painted Porsche-branded calipers over cross-drilled and ventilated discs. The car is equipped with Porsche Active Suspension Management (PASM) and Power Steering Plus. The front inner CV boots were replaced in March 2023.

The heated and ventilated power-adjustable sport front seats are upholstered in Cognac, while Espresso leather covers the upper portions of the dashboard and door panels. Porsche-branded floor mats line the footwells, and additional appointments include aluminum pedals, an aftermarket accessory mount, PCM with navigation, adaptive cruise control with Porsche Active Safe, a Bose sound system, dual-zone automatic climate control, and cruise control. The passenger airbag wiring harness was replaced in March 2023, and replacement air conditioning hoses were installed in April 2023, at which time the air conditioning refrigerant was recharged.

The heated multifunction steering wheel frames a central tachometer with a 7,600-rpm redline as well as a 200-mph speedometer and gauges for oil temperature, oil pressure, coolant temperature, and fuel level. The optional Sport Chrono Package added a stopwatch atop the dashboard. The digital odometer indicates 99k miles, approximately 7k of which were added under current ownership.

The 3.8-liter flat-six was factory rated at 400 horsepower and 325 lb-ft of torque. Power is sent to all four wheels through a seven-speed PDK dual-clutch transaxle and Porsche Torque Vectoring Plus with an electronically locking rear differential. The car is equipped with an optional sport exhaust system. An oil change was performed in January 2024.
The Carfax report is free of accidents or other reported damage.

This 1987 Mercedes-Benz 300E shows 67k miles and is finished in Artic White over red MB-Tex upholstery. Powered by a 3.0-liter M103 inline-six paired with a four-speed automatic transmission, the car is equipped with 15″ Gullideckel alloy wheels, a sunroof, power-adjustable front seats, a cassette stereo, automatic climate control, and cruise control. It was purchased by the selling dealer in 2024 following registration history in New York, Ohio, and Georgia, and work performed in preparation for the sale included replacing the spark plugs, spark plug wires, fuel filter, distributor cap and rotor, and valve cover gasket. This W124 300E is offered in New York with manufacturer’s literature and a clean Georgia title.

The car is finished in Arctic White (147) with black bumper trim. Features include a sunroof, headlight wipers and washers, fog lights, a power antenna, and a mono-blade windshield wiper. An April 2024 entry on the Carfax report lists “minor damage” with no additional information, and the selling dealer notes that the left quarter panel has been repainted. Close-up photographs of the exterior finish and trim are shown in the gallery below.
Silver 15″ Gullideckel alloy wheels are mounted with General Altimax RT43 tires that have 2021 and 2022 date codes. Braking is handled by ventilated front and solid rear disc brakes with ABS.

The cabin features seating upholstered in red MB-Tex along with wood trim and a color-coordinated lower dashboard, center console, door panels, and carpets. Interior appointments include power-adjustable front seats, a cassette stereo, automatic climate control, a passenger airbag, cruise control, and air conditioning, the latter of which was recharged in preparation for the sale.

The four-spoke steering wheel frames VDO instrumentation including a 160-mph speedometer and a tachometer as well as an analog clock and gauges for coolant temperature, oil pressure, and fuel level. The six-digit odometer shows 67k miles.

The 3.0-liter M103 inline-six was factory-rated at 177 horsepower and 188 lb-ft of torque. The Carfax report indicates that the oil was changed and the spark plugs, spark plug wires, fuel filter, distributor cap and rotor, and valve cover gasket were replaced in April.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through a four-speed automatic transmission.
A stamped service booklet and manufacturer’s literature will accompany the sale.
The Carfax report lists the aforementioned April 204 damage.

This 1995 Chevrolet Camaro Z28 convertible has been modified with first-generation-style bodywork and refinished in yellow over graphite leather and yellow houndstooth cloth. It is powered by a 5.7-liter LT1 V8 linked with a four-speed automatic transmission and a limited-slip differential and equipped with a black convertible soft top, a cowl induction hood, a decklid spoiler, black 17″ and 18″ wheels, a power-adjustable driver seat, air conditioning, cruise control, power windows, and a Delco CD stereo. Acquired by the selling dealer in 2023, this modified Camaro Z28 convertible shows 118k miles and is offered with a clean Carfax report and a clean South Carolina title.

The car was modified with bodywork resembling a first-generation Camaro and refinished in yellow with black decals under previous ownership. Exterior details include a black convertible soft top, a cowl induction hood, and a decklid spoiler.

Black 17″ and 18″ wheels feature silver lips and are mounted with 245/45 Westlake SA-07 tires up front and 285/35 Lexani LXUHP-207 rubber out back. Braking is handled by four-wheel ventilated discs with ABS.

The front bucket seats and contoured rear seats are trimmed in graphite leather with yellow houndstooth inserts. Appointments include a power-adjustable driver seat, air conditioning, cruise control, a Delco CD stereo, and power windows and locks.

The leather-wrapped steering wheel frames a 150-mph speedometer, a 7k-rpm tachometer, and gauges for voltage, oil pressure, fuel level, and coolant temperature. The six-digit odometer shows 118k miles, approximately 1,500 of which were added by the selling dealer.
The 5.7-liter LT1 V8 was factory rated at 275 horsepower and 325 lb-ft of torque.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through a four-speed automatic transmission and a limited-slip differential.
The Carfax report is free of accidents or other damage.

This 1946 Ford Super Deluxe coupe is said to have been delivered new to Jim Bush Ford in Ashland, Oregon, and has remained with the same owner since 1957. A refurbishment in the 2000s involved re-trimming the interior in white and installing a 239ci flathead V8 joined to a three-speed automatic transmission and an 8” rear end. Power-assisted four-wheel disc brakes were also added along with a Mustang II front suspension. Other equipment includes an Offenhauser intake manifold, dual Holley 94 carburetors, Edelbrock cylinder heads, American Racing 15” wheels, exhaust headers, and an electric trunk lid popper. This Super Deluxe coupe is now offered on dealer consignment at no reserve with manufacturer’s literature, a workshop manual, and a clean Oregon title.

The car was repainted in black in the 1990s and features a split windshield, a red-accented grille, aftermarket supplementary turn signals, and a rear bumper embossed with a Ford emblem. The trunk lid hardware has been shaved, and an electric popper is operated with a switch inside the fuel filler door. Delamination is visible in the pop-out quarter windows, and bubbling paint, cracks, and blemishes around the car can be viewed in the gallery. The listing photos were taken in 2023.

This is a relist after the vehicle was listed on BaT in November 2023 and withdrawn due to a leak from the transmission, which has since been repaired. The associated record is provided in the gallery.

American Racing Torq Thrust 15” wheels are mounted with older BFGoodrich Radial T/A tires that measure 205/60 up front and 275/60 out back. The suspension has been lowered and modified with a Mustang II subframe and coilovers up front. Braking is handled by power-assisted discs at all four corners with Wilwood rear calipers. The brakes were adjusted in preparation for the sale, and cracks in the tires are noted.

The cabin has been reupholstered in white, and black carpets line the floors. Custom pinstriping adorns the black dashboard, which houses an AM radio and a clock. The sun visors are missing, and discoloration and wear on the interior surfaces can be viewed in the gallery along with pitting on the interior brightwork.

The Grant steering wheel fronts a 100-mph speedometer and inoperative auxiliary gauges, while AutoMeter supplementary gauges have been added below the dash. The oil pressure gauge does not work, and a secondary unit has been mounted in the engine compartment. The five-digit odometer shows 9k miles. Total mileage is unknown.

The 239ci Flathead V8 is said to have been sourced from a 1951 Mercury and is equipped with an Offenhauser intake manifold, dual Holley 94 carburetors, and finned Edelbrock cylinder heads. Tubular headers flow into a dual exhaust system with polished finishers, and the drivetrain electrical system has been converted to 12-volt operation. Work performed in preparation for the sale has reportedly included rebuilding the carburetors and repairing the radiator. The selling dealer notes that the choke mechanisms are not hooked up, and the electric pusher fan for the radiator must be operated manually while driving.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through a C4 three-speed automatic transmission and an 8” rear end. A transmission cooler has been mounted to the underside of the passenger floor.
A workshop manual and manufacturer’s literature will accompany the car.
Historical images are presented in the gallery.

This 1955 Fiat 600 is finished in gray over red vinyl and is powered by a 633cc inline-four paired with a four-speed manual transaxle. Equipment includes rear-hinged doors, sliding side windows, a vented decklid, and 12″ steel wheels. The car spent time in Italy before being brought to Canada from the US by the selling dealer. This 600 is offered by the selling dealer in Canada with a tool kit and Ontario registration.

Unveiled at the Geneva Motor Show in March 1955 as the successor to the 500 Topolino, the Fiat 600 was the company’s first rear-engined car and was produced through 1969 at the Mirafiori assembly facility in Turin, Italy. This first-year example is finished in gray and was repainted some time ago. The vented engine cover wears a Fiat 600 badge, and further details include sliding side windows, rear-hinged doors, and polished bumpers.

Ivory-finished 12″ steel wheels wear polished Fiat-branded hubcaps and are mounted with 5.20″ whitewall tires. A full-size spare is stored in the front trunk compartment. The suspension features a transverse leaf spring setup at the front paired with semi-trailing arms with coil springs out back. Stopping power is provided by four-wheel drums.
The cabin houses a pair of front bucket seats and a rear bench trimmed in red vinyl with white piping. Rubber liners cover the floors.
An ivory-finished steering wheel fronts a 110-km/h speedometer flanked by auxiliary gauges. The five-digit odometer shows 60k kilometers (~37k miles).
The water-cooled 633cc inline-four features a single carburetor. The selling dealer states that the fuel pump and water pump were replaced in Italy.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through a four-speed manual transaxle.
The vehicle does not have a title and is being sold on its Ontario registration, which serves as the ownership document in Ontario, Canada.

This 1969 Plymouth Barracuda convertible was acquired by the seller around 2013 and was subsequently refurbished with installation of a 5.7-liter Hemi V8 and a five-speed automatic transmission as well as a repaint in orange with black stripes and trim. Other features include an AlterKtion K-member, power-assisted rack-and-pinion steering, Wilwood front disc brakes, five-spoke 17″ wheels, a TTi dual exhaust system, a black convertible top, a rear wing, black leather front seats, power windows, power locks, a push-button starter, aftermarket gauges, air conditioning, a Pioneer Mixtrax touchscreen infotainment system, and an aftermarket audio system. The transmission’s computer was replaced in preparation for the sale. This modified Barracuda is now offered with service records and a clean Arizona title in the name of the seller’s spouse.

Plymouth manufactured 1,442 Barracuda convertibles for 1969. This example is said to have been refinished in orange around 2016, and the black convertible top has been replaced. Features include black stripes on the hood as well as black bumpers, a black grille, black trim, black windshield-wiper arms, a black driver-side mirror, a black rear wing, a black tail panel, a chrome flip-up fuel cap, and chrome dual tailpipes. Touch-up paintwork has been performed, and the rear-window alignment to the top and the door on the passenger side is imperfect.

The 17″ wheels have black spokes, bright lips, and Retro-branded center caps. Pirelli Cinturato P7 tires measure 205/50 in front and 225/50 at the rear. An AlterKtion front K-member connects to Viking Performance front coilovers, a front anti-roll bar, and power-assisted rack-and-pinion steering. The power-assisted braking system is composed of Wilwood front discs paired with rear drums.

Front bucket seats sourced from a Chrysler 300 are trimmed in black leather and have Chrysler logos in the seatbacks. The rear seats also are upholstered in black, and seatbelts are provided for four occupants. A center console from a Chrysler 300 has been added along with aftermarket air conditioning, a push-button starter, power windows, power locks, and a Pioneer Mixtrax touchscreen head unit. The air conditioning was serviced in 2023.

An aftermarket three-spoke steering wheel frames aftermarket instrumentation consisting of a 140-mph speedometer, an 8k-rpm tachometer, and gauges for oil pressure, water temperature, fuel level, and battery voltage. The digital odometer indicates approximately 50 miles. Total mileage is unknown.
The battery has been relocated to the trunk compartment, which also houses a JL Audio subwoofer and a Kenwood amplifier.

The 5.7-liter Hemi V8 is said to have been sourced from a Chrysler 300 and installed by the seller. A K&N air filter and exhaust headers are fitted, and the car has been rewired. The engine bay was repainted more recently than the rest of the vehicle, according to the seller. The car’s chassis number indicates that it was originally powered by a 318ci V8.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through an NAG1 five-speed automatic transmission that was rebuilt and installed under current ownership. The transmission’s computer was replaced in May 2024.

This 1995 Ferrari 456 GT is a Canadian-market example powered by a 5.5-liter F116 V12 paired with a six-speed manual transaxle. Finished in Canna di Fucile over Beige Tradizione Connolly leather, it is equipped with a limited-slip differential, 17″ five-spoke alloy wheels, a gated shifter, pop-up headlights, power-adjustable front seats, automatic climate control, and a factory stereo linked with a CD changer. The car was sold on BaT in June 2020 before being imported to the US later that year, and it was acquired by the selling dealer in 2024. Work in preparation for the sale is said to have included a timing belt service and replacement of the rear shocks and nitrogen spheres. This 456 GT is offered in New York with an owner’s manual, a tool kit, an accident-free Carfax report, and a clean Connecticut title.

The Pininfarina-designed aluminum and composite bodywork is finished in Canna di Fucile and features pop-up headlights, integrated fog lights, and polished quadruple exhaust tips exiting through the rear valance. HID headlights were installed under previous ownership.

Silver 17″ five-spoke alloy wheels are mounted with Continental ExtremeContact tires measuring 255/45 up front and 285/40 out back. Self-adjusting dampers and self-leveling rear suspension were standard equipment. Stopping power is provided by Ferrari-branded four-piston brake calipers over ventilated rotors at each corner. The rear shocks and nitrogen spheres were replaced in preparation for the sale.

The cabin features Beige Tradizione Connolly leather upholstery that extends from the seating surfaces to the center console, lower dashboard, and door panels. Equipment includes power-adjustable front seats, a gated shifter, a stereo, a remote 10-disc CD changer, and automatic climate control.

The leather-wrapped steering wheel frames Veglia Borletti instrumentation including a 320-km/h speedometer and a 10k-rpm tachometer. An analog clock and gauges for fuel level, coolant temperature, oil pressure, and oil temperature are located in the center stack. The six-digit odometer shows 16k kilometers (~10k miles). The Carfax report indicates that an “Exceeds Mechanical Limits” title was issued in 2021, and total mileage is unknown.

The 5.5-liter F116 V12 features four valves per cylinder, Bosch Motronic fuel injection, and dry-sump lubrication. It was factory rated at 436 horsepower and 406 lb-ft of torque, which is routed to the rear wheels through a six-speed manual transaxle and a limited-slip differential. The selling dealer notes that a timing belt service was performed in preparation for the sale along with a coolant flush.
The Carfax report lists the aforementioned Exceeds Mechanical Limits title issuances and at least one open recall.

This 2006 Ferrari F430 is a black-over-black example that has 29k miles and has been fitted with 19″ Scuderia wheels, a lowered ride height, a backup camera, Fabspeed exhaust headers, carbon-fiber mirror caps and door grab handles, a fire extinguisher, and wheel spacers. Powered by a 4.3-liter DOHC V8 paired with a six-speed F1 automated transaxle, the car is further equipped with an electronically controlled limited-slip differential, Brembo carbon-ceramic brake rotors, Scuderia Ferrari fender shields, and carbon-fiber exterior and interior accents. This F430 was purchased by the owner in 2022 and is now offered on dealer consignment with a car cover, a clean Carfax report, and a clean Washington title.

The Pininfarina-designed body is finished in Nero Daytona and has a carbon-fiber rear grille and mirror caps. Additional details include xenon headlights with washers, Scuderia Ferrari fender shields, side air intakes, a backup camera, and quad exhaust tips exiting on either side of the rear diffuser. Blemishes are located on the rear bumper cover and diffuser, and paint chips are visible on the left door.

The 19″ multi-spoke Scuderia wheels are equipped with spacers and are mounted with 225/35 front and 285/35 rear Pirelli P Zero tires. Braking is handled by yellow-finished brake calipers fitted over Brembo carbon-ceramic rotors, and the car has a lowered ride height. According to the seller, a left CV boot is worn.

The cockpit features bucket seats upholstered in Nero leather with Cavallino Rampante logos on the headrests and yellow stitching that extends to the dashboard, center console, and door panels. Carbon-fiber trim accents the cabin, and additional appointments include machined aluminum pedals, a CD stereo, navigation, F430-branded floor mats, a fire extinguisher, carbon-fiber door grab handles, and power windows and locks. The air conditioning system does not work, and wear is present on the driver’s seat.

The leather- and carbon-fiber-trimmed steering wheel is equipped with an engine-start button as well as a manettino dial for control of dynamic settings. Instrumentation includes a central tachometer with an 8,500-rpm redline as well as a 220-mph speedometer and gauges for coolant temperature, oil temperature, and oil pressure. The digital odometer indicates 29k miles, approximately 2k of which were added during current ownership.

The mid-mounted 4.3-liter F136 V8 features Bosch Motronic engine management, a dry-sump lubrication system, and Fabspeed exhaust headers. Power is sent to the rear wheels through a six-speed F1 automated transaxle and an electronically controlled limited-slip differential. An oil change was performed in preparation for the sale. According to the seller, the engine mounts are worn, and oil residue is located on the timing cover.
The Carfax report is free of accidents or other reported damage.
There is currently a lien out on the car, and the owner’s lender will need to be paid off before the title can be transferred to the new owner.

This 1979 International Harvester Scout II was acquired by the seller in 2022 and underwent a refurbishment that was completed in preparation for the sale. Work included rebuilding the three-speed automatic transmission, repainting the exterior metallic gray, refreshing the interior, and replacing the torque converter, wheels, tires, steering wheel, steering column, starter, and valve covers. The truck is powered by a replacement 350ci, and additional equipment includes a Holley intake manifold, an aluminum radiator, Shorty exhaust headers, a Flowmaster muffler, a dual-range transfer case, a black hardtop, 15″ aftermarket wheels, Warn manually locking front hubs, tubular bumpers, a Pioneer stereo, and an aftermarket subwoofer and speakers. This Scout II is offered at no reserve with service records and a clean Texas title in the seller’s name.
The truck was repainted metallic gray, and equipment includes tubular bumpers, a black removable hardtop, and a receiver hitch.

The 15″ aftermarket wheels are mounted with BFGoodrich All-Terrain T/A tires. The truck is equipped with Warn manually locking front hubs, and stopping power is provided by front disc and rear drum brakes. The Pitman arm, wheels, and tires were replaced during the refurbishment.
The front bucket seats and rear bench are trimmed in black vinyl. The dashboard was updated and an aftermarket stereo, subwoofer, and speakers were installed during the build.

The three-spoke Grant steering wheel is mounted to a tilting column and fronts a horizontal 120-mph speedometer and gauges for temperature, oil pressure, amperage, and fuel level. The five-digit odometer shows 28k miles, approximately 500 of which were added under current ownership. Total mileage is unknown. The speedometer cable was replaced during the refurbishment.

The replacement 350ci V8 was installed under prior ownership and is equipped with a Holley Street Dominator intake manifold, an aluminum radiator, Shorty exhaust headers, and a Flowmaster muffler. The starter and valve covers are said to have been replaced under current ownership.

The A727 three-speed automatic transmission routes power to the rear or all four wheels through a Spicer dual-range transfer case. The transmission was rebuilt and the torque converter was replaced during the refurbishment.

This 2000 Mercedes-Benz SL600 has 52k miles and is powered by a 6.0-liter V12 paired with a five-speed automatic transmission. Finished in Brilliant Silver Metallic over black Exclusive leather upholstery, the car has a black soft top, a body-color hardtop, 18″ AMG Monoblock wheels, xenon headlights, fog lights, an Adaptive Damping System (ADS) with all-wheel automatic level control, heated power-adjustable seats, a Bose sound system, a CD changer, a mobile phone, and automatic climate control. This R129 was acquired by the selling dealer in 2024 and is now offered with the owner’s manual, a clean Carfax report, and a clean New York title.

The car is finished in Brilliant Silver Metallic and has a black soft top in addition to a body-color hardtop. Additional exterior details include xenon headlights, fog lights, and fender air vents. Paint meter readings as well as close-up photos of exterior imperfections are provided in the gallery.

The 18″ AMG Monoblock wheels are mounted with staggered-width Michelin tires. The car is equipped with Automatic Slip Control (ASR) and an Adaptive Damping System (ADS) with all-wheel automatic level control. Stopping power is provided by four-wheel disc brakes. The left-front wheel has curb damage.

The heated power-adjustable seats are upholstered in black Exclusive leather along with wood accents on the doors and center console. Carpeted floor mats line the footwells, and additional appointments include a deployable roll bar, seat position memory, a Bose sound system, cruise control, a mobile phone, and automatic climate control. The interior wood trim has cracks, the driver’s seat is worn, and a blemish is present on the dashboard. The center console was repaired in November 2023, according to the Carfax report.

The leather- and wood-trimmed steering wheel fronts a 160-mph speedometer, a 7k-rpm tachometer, a clock, and gauges for coolant temperature, oil temperature, fuel economy, and fuel level. The digital odometer indicates 52k miles.

The 6.0-liter M120 V12 was factory rated at 389 horsepower and 420 lb-ft of torque. Power is routed to the rear wheels via a five-speed automatic transmission. According to the Carfax report, work in 2024 included replacement of exhaust components in addition to the air intake hose, transmission fluid, and oxygen sensor.
The Carfax report is free of accidents or other reported damage.

This 2019 Chevrolet Corvette Grand Sport coupe is a black-over-black example that was purchased new by the seller at Good Chevrolet of Renton, Washington, and was optioned with a seven-speed manual gearbox, which is paired with a 6.2-liter LT1 V8. The car has an MGW short shifter, a limited-slip differential, black aluminum 19″ and 20″ split-spoke wheels, Magnetic Ride Control, xenon headlights, a removable roof panel, a rear spoiler, window tint, power-adjustable GT bucket seats, a Bose sound system, and MyLink infotainment. This C7 Grand Sport has 20k miles and is now offered in California with a clean Carfax report and a clean Washington title.

The Grand Sport features a front splitter, rocker panel extensions, and a wicker-bill rear spoiler as well as wider front fenders and rear quarter panels compared to the Stingray. This example is finished in black and has xenon headlights, a removable roof panel, a vented carbon-fiber hood, window tint, power-adjustable mirrors, and quadruple exhaust outlets. Paint protection film has been applied to the front end, A-pillars, side skirts, and rear quarter panels, per the seller. The front spoiler has scratches.

Black-finished aluminum 19″ and 20″ split-spoke wheels are mounted with staggered-width Michelin Pilot Super Sport tires. The car is equipped with Magnetic Ride Control and an Active Handling System with all-speed traction control. Stopping power is provided by four-wheel slotted and ventilated rotors. Replacement rear brake pads were reportedly installed in 2023.

The cockpit features power-adjustable GT bucket seats upholstered in Jet Black leather and joined by a color-coordinated dashboard, center console, door panels, and carpets. Interior appointments include a Bose sound system, carpeted floor mats, an MGW short shifter, automatic climate control, cruise control, keyless entry, and a touchscreen infotainment system.

The multifunction steering wheel frames a central digital tachometer, a 205-mph speedometer, and supplementary gauges. The digital odometer indicates 20k miles, all of which were added under current ownership.
The 6.2-liter LT1 V8 was factory rated at 460 horsepower and 465 lb-ft of torque. An oil change was performed and the differential fluid was replaced in 2023.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through a seven-speed manual gearbox and a limited-slip differential.
The Carfax report is free of accidents or other reported damage.
There is currently a lien out on the car, and the seller’s lender will need to be paid off before the title can be transferred to the new owner.

This 1932 Ford Model B was purchased by the current owner in 2008 as a project without a body. Subsequent work included installing fiberglass Tudor bodywork from Gibbon and fiberglass fenders from Wescott as well as a 201ci inline-four that was rebuilt with an Alexander OHV head, dual Stromberg 97 carburetors, and a Datsun dual-coil distributor. The car is also equipped with hydraulic brakes, tube shocks, 16″ wire wheels, a steel Rootlieb hood, and a three-speed manual transmission with 1939 Ford gears. The cabin retains a three-spoke steering wheel and has been fitted with lap seatbelts, Stewart-Warner gauges, and a Model T-style “ahooga” horn. This Model B is now offered by the seller on behalf of the current owner with service records and a clean Washington title in the owner’s name.

The car was acquired by the current owner as a frame with a firewall, and it was then fitted with an unpainted Tudor body from Gibbon Fiberglass. The fenders and grille shell are also unpainted fiberglass and were sourced from Wescott’s Auto. Additional work included installing a 20-louver steel hood from Rootlieb after it was painted black, and the car is further equipped with turn signals, dual taillights, and sideview mirrors.

Black-painted wire wheels wear chrome hubcaps and are mounted with 6.00–16 front and 7.00–16 rear Firestone bias-ply tires. The Model B rides on a 106″ wheelbase and features front and rear transverse leaf springs. This example is equipped with tube shocks and four-wheel hydraulic drum brakes.

The cabin features front seats trimmed in gray cloth, and additional equipment includes lap belts and a Model T-style “ahooga” horn mounted between the front seats. Un-upholstered rear bench seat springs are installed, and the car is not fitted with a headliner or carpets.

The three-spoke steering wheel fronts a dash with an engine-turned panel housing a Stewart-Warner 160-mph speedometer and auxiliary gauges, while additional readouts are positioned in front of the driver and a tachometer is mounted under the dash to the left of the steering column. The odometer shows 650 miles, representing the distance the car has been driven since completion of the build.

The 201ci inline-four was built in 2009 by Jay Steel of Taylor, California.
