A head-up display is equipped as standard as are driver aids comprising lane-keep assist, rear cross-traffic alert, side blind-zone alert, and forward collision alert. The digital odometer indicates 2 miles.

The mid-mounted 5.5-liter LT6 V8 is equipped with a flat-plane crankshaft and was factory rated at 670 horsepower and 460 lb-ft of torque. The car came equipped from the factory with the Engine Appearance Package as well as a performance exhaust system with driver-selectable modes.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through an eight-speed dual-clutch automatic transaxle along with an electronic limited-slip differential.
The window sticker notes initial delivery to Taylor & Sons Chevrolet in Sandpoint, Idaho, and lists factory equipment, colors, options, and a total vehicle price of $159,350.
The Carfax report has not yet generated any entries.

This car does not have a title as it has never been sold to a private party owner. It is being offered with its Manufacturer’s Certificate of Origin, and the selling dealer will assist the buyer with registration, titling, and tax collection. The selling dealer notes that per General Motors, the vehicle must be sold and registered in the US, and the car may not be sold to a broker, a wholesale dealer, or a retail dealer. The buyer will be required to agree to retain the vehicle for a minimum of six months from the date of purchase or the warranty will be null and void for any subsequent owners.

This 2004 BMW 330i sedan has 14k miles following registration in Pennsylvania with the original owner until 2024. The car is finished in Black Sapphire Metallic over black Montana leather and powered by a 3.0-liter inline-six paired with a six-speed manual transmission. It was ordered with the ZHP Performance Package, which added revised aerodynamic bodywork, a sport suspension, and a revised final drive ratio. Features include heated front sport seats, 18″ M double-spoke wheels, an electric sunroof, xenon headlights, and a Harman Kardon sound system. Recently acquired by the selling dealer, this ZHP is now offered at no reserve with the owner’s manual, a clean Carfax report, and a clean New Jersey title.

The car is finished in Black Sapphire Metallic and features an aerodynamic package that includes revised bumper covers and side skirts in addition to black Shadowline trim and a decklid spoiler. Additional features include xenon headlights, fog lamps, an electric sunroof, rain-sensing windshield wipers, and dual exhaust outlets.

Silver 18″ M double-spoke wheels are mounted with Michelin Pilot Sport tires measuring 225/40 up front and 255/35 out back. The ZHP Performance Package added a stiffer sport suspension, revised control arms, and larger anti-roll bars when compared to the standard E46. The car is also equipped with Dynamic Stability Control (DSC).

The cabin features heated front sport seats trimmed in black Montana leather complemented by black cube aluminum trim. Amenities include a Harman Kardon sound system, automatic climate control, cruise control, and a BMW Business CD stereo. The right airbag assembly was replaced in August 2015 per the Carfax report.

The microsuede-wrapped multi-function M sport steering wheel frames a 155-mph speedometer, a tachometer with a 6,800-rpm redline, and gauges for coolant temperature, instant fuel economy, and fuel level. The digital odometer indicates 14k miles.

The 3.0-liter M54 inline-six features upgraded engine management software along with revised camshafts for a factory rating of 235 horsepower and 222 lb-ft of torque in ZHP specification. The Carfax report notes that the crankshaft position sensor was replaced in October 2023.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through a six-speed manual transmission.
The Carfax report is free of accidents or other reported damage.

This 1978 AMC Pacer D/L station wagon is finished in tan with faux woodgrain paneling over tan cloth upholstery and powered by a 258ci inline-six paired with a three-speed automatic transmission. Steel 14″ wheels with full covers are fitted as well as front disc brakes, chrome bumpers, air conditioning, a folding rear bench seat, and a Panasonic eight-track player. The car was reportedly sold new at Jim Marsh Motors in Las Vegas, Nevada, and acquired by the current owner in August 2022. This Pacer wagon is offered at no reserve on behalf of the current owner with a clean California title in the current owner’s name.

The station wagon variant of the Pacer was fitted with a wider rear hatch compared to the standard model, and the D/L trim package added special wheel covers and exterior trim. This example is finished in Sand Tan with faux woodgrain paneling on the sides and rear hatch and features dual power-adjustable side mirrors, roof rails, pop-out rear quarter windows, and chrome bumpers.

Steel 14” wheels wear full covers sporting body-color accents and are mounted with mismatched thin-whitewall tires. The car is equipped with power steering, and stopping power is provided by disc brakes up front and drums out back.

The front bucket seats and folding rear bench are upholstered in tan cloth and are accompanied by color-coordinated door panels and carpets. Additional appointments include woodgrain dashboard trim, sheepskin front seat covers, an analog clock, a Panasonic eight-track player, and air conditioning.

The two-spoke steering wheel fronts a 90-mph speedometer, a fuel-level gauge, a clock, and an array of warning lights. The five-digit odometer shows 47k miles, approximately 2,000 of which have been added under current ownership.
The 258ci inline-six is equipped with a two-barrel carburetor. An oil change was performed under current ownership.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through a three-speed automatic transmission that was reportedly rebuilt approximately 4k miles ago.
The car last passed a smog test for the state of California in May 2024.

This 1981 Chevrolet C10 Silverado pickup was acquired by the seller in 2021 and subsequent work consisted of installing replacement air conditioning components, Classic Instruments gauges, and a 383ci V8 linked with a TH350 three-speed automatic transmission and a limited-slip differential with 4.11:1 gears. Finished in blue and silver over black vinyl upholstery, the truck is equipped with air conditioning, power steering, power front disc brakes, 15″ Rally wheels, Belltech shock absorbers, a Weiand intake manifold, a Holley four-barrel carburetor, an HEI distributor, and a CVF Racing serpentine system as well as long-tube exhaust headers, and an aluminum radiator with dual electric fans. This C10 is now offered with a clean Wyoming title in the seller’s name.

The truck was repainted in blue and silver under prior ownership and details include a bowtie hood ornament, stacked rectangular headlights, dual side mirrors, Silverado badges, and chrome bumpers. Paint blemishes are shown in the gallery.

The 15″ Rally wheels wear trim rings and bowtie center caps and are mounted with 255/70 BFGoodrich Radial T/A white-letter tires. The truck is fitted with power steering and Belltech Street Performance shock absorbers, and power-assisted front discs and rear drums provide braking. The master cylinder was replaced in preparation for the sale.

The bench seat is trimmed in black vinyl upholstery and interior appointments include air conditioning, a stainless steel instrument panel surround, rubber floor mats, and a RetroSound digital stereo wired to aftermarket speakers and an amplified subwoofer.

The two-spoke steering wheel frames a Classic Instruments Velocity 160-mph speedometer, a tachometer, and auxiliary gauges. The five-digit odometer shows 982 miles, all of which were added under current ownership. Total mileage is unknown.

The 383ci V8 was installed in 2023 and is fitted with a Weiand intake manifold, a Holley four-barrel carburetor, an HEI distributor, a CVF Racing serpentine system, a Chevrolet-script air cleaner and valve covers, long-tube exhaust headers, and an aluminum radiator with dual electric cooling fans.

Power is routed to the rear wheels through a TH350 three-speed automatic transmission and a limited-slip differential with 4.11:1 gears. A custom dual exhaust with Flowmaster mufflers has been fitted.
The Carfax report shows no accidents or other damage and lists history in Montana and Wyoming.

This 1983 Honda ATC 200E Big Red was purchased new by the seller’s uncle and is powered by an air-cooled 192cc four-stroke single that drives the rear axle via a dual-range five-speed transmission with an automatic clutch. The three-wheeler is finished in red and equipped with a black vinyl solo seat, trail lighting, a rear storage compartment, and front and rear cargo racks as well as a Keihin carburetor, both recoil and electric starters, a telescopic fork, silver-finished 9″ aluminum wheels, and drum brakes. Following eight years in storage, the ATC was acquired by the seller in 2023 and received a replacement battery and spark plug in March 2024. This ATC 200E is now offered at no reserve for off-road use only with a bill of sale.

The three-wheeler is finished in red with two-tone blue and white decals accenting the 2.3-gallon fuel tank. Mudflaps are attached to the three plastic fenders, and additional details include front and rear cargo racks, a black vinyl solo seat, trail lighting, a rear storage compartment, a clevis pin hitch, and folding foot pegs. The taillight lens is cracked, the rear fenders are scratched, the rear decals have portions missing, and corrosion is visible on metal surfaces including the fuel tank, frame, and cargo racks.

Silver-finished 9″ aluminum wheels were mounted with 25×12.00″ Nanco knobby tires in 2008. Braking is handled by drums mounted to the front hub and rear axle, and the ATC’s only suspension consists of a leading-axle telescopic fork with black gaiters. The right-rear tire has cracks in the sidewall and corrosion is visible on the wheels and fork lowers.

The chrome handlebar is mounted between a keyed ignition switch and a choke knob. It is equipped with black waffle-pattern grips as well as a thumb throttle on the right and lighting and ignition switchgear on the left. The ATC is not equipped with an odometer or other instrumentation, therefore true mileage is unknown.

The air-cooled 192cc SOHC four-stroke single is equipped with a 22mm Keihin carburetor, both electric and recoil starters, and an exhaust system that exits below the rear bodywork. Work in March 2024 included changing the oil and replacing the battery and spark plug. Scrapes are visible on the clutch cover and corrosion is visible on the exhaust system.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through an automatic clutch, a dual-range five-speed transmission, and an enclosed drive chain.
The ATC does not have a title or registration. It is being sold for off-road use only on a bill of sale.

This 1955 Willys station wagon was refurbished between 2006 and 2008, which included repainting the exterior blue and reupholstering the seats in beige and white vinyl. The truck is powered by a 226ci inline-six mated to a three-speed manual transmission, and additional equipment includes 15″ steel wheels, manually locking front hubs, chrome bumpers, a two-piece windshield, a winch, and a cabin heater. This Willys wagon was acquired by the selling dealer in January 2024 and is offered with refurbishment photos and a clean Oregon title.
The body was removed from the frame and repainted blue during the refurbishment. Equipment includes chrome bumpers, a two-piece windshield, a PTO-driven winch, and roof bars.
Blue-finished 15″ steel wheels wear Specialty Tires of America Super Traction tires. The truck is equipped with manually locking front hubs.
The seating surfaces are trimmed in beige and white vinyl. Appointments include body-color metal surfaces, a heater, and black vinyl flooring.
The two-spoke steering wheel fronts a 90-mph speedometer and supplementary gauges. The five-digit odometer shows 1,300 miles. Total mileage is unknown.
The 226ci inline-six sends power to the rear or all four wheels through a three-speed manual transmission and a dual-range transfer case.

This 1968 Chevrolet Corvette convertible was acquired by the selling dealer in 2015, and it was refinished in orange in 2016 and the 427ci V8 was rebuilt in 2022. The car is equipped with a four-speed manual transmission, a black vinyl removable hardtop, retractable headlights, 15″ Rally wheels, four-wheel disc brakes, Bilstein shocks, a Dragvette 6-link rear suspension, a Holley four-barrel carburetor, Mickey Thompson valve covers, a Be Cool aluminum radiator, an AM/FM radio, and a cabin heater. Additional work in 2022 included the replacement of the tires, rear wheels, rear hub mounting studs, fuel tank, spark plugs, intake manifold, exhaust manifold, and thermostat. This C3 convertible is now offered by the selling dealer with a 2022 service invoice and a clean New Jersey title.

The car was finished at the factory in Corvette Bronze, and a repaint in orange is said to have been completed in 2016. Features include a black vinyl removable hardtop, a cowl-induction hood, retractable headlights, chrome bumpers, side vents, and dual exhaust outlets. The rear luggage rack was installed in 2022. Paint imperfections are shown up close in the gallery.

The silver-painted 15″ Rally wheels feature chrome hubcaps and trim rings and are mounted with 225/60 BFGoodrich Radial T/A tires that show sidewall cracking. The rear wheels and wheel studs were also replaced during the same service. Braking is handled by discs at each corner. Bilstein shocks and a Dragvette Products 6-Link rear suspension system are fitted.

The cabin features bucket seats upholstered in black vinyl as well as color-coordinated door panels and carpets. Amenities include an AM/FM radio, Corvette-emblem floor mats, and a cabin heater. Wear on the interior surfaces is shown in the gallery.

The three-spoke steering wheel frames a 160-mph speedometer and a tachometer with a 6,500-rpm redline, while instrumentation found in the center stack includes an analog clock along with displays for fuel level, coolant temperature, oil pressure, and amperage. The five-digit odometer shows 5k miles, approximately 100 of which were added under current ownership. Total mileage is unknown.

The 427ci V8 was rebuilt in 2022, and additional work involved replacing the intake manifold, exhaust manifolds, fuel tank, thermostat, water pump, spark plugs, and air cleaner assembly. Equipment includes a Holley four-barrel carburetor, Mickey Thompson valve covers, an MSD distributor and ignition coil, and a Be Cool aluminum radiator. The choke was removed under previous ownership.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through a four-speed manual transmission.
Decoding the trim tag reveals:

This 2009 Mercedes-Benz E350 4MATIC wagon is powered by a 3.5-liter V6 that drives all four wheels through a five-speed automatic transmission. The car is finished in Arctic White over beige MB-Tex leather upholstery, and equipment includes a sunroof, 17″ multi-spoke alloy wheels, heated power-adjustable front seats, fold-down third-row seating, a Harman Kardon LOGIC7 surround sound system, a Sony infotainment system with Bluetooth connectivity, and dual-zone automatic climate control. The car was purchased by the current owner in 2022 following registration history in New York and California, and it now has 101k miles. This E350 4MATIC wagon is offered on dealer consignment at no reserve with a clean Carfax report and a clean California title.

The car is finished in Arctic White (650) and features a sunroof, a rear window wiper, tinted windows, a power-operated tailgate, roof rails, and fog lights. Close-up photographs of the exterior finish and trim are shown in the gallery below.

Silver 17″ multi-spoke alloy wheels are mounted with Continental tires. Stopping power is provided by ventilated discs at each corner, and the car is equipped with Airmatic air suspension and an Adaptive Damping System (ADS II).

The heated power-adjustable front seats are upholstered in beige MB-Tex, and interior amenities include a Harman Kardon LOGIC7 surround sound system, split-folding second-row seats, dual-zone automatic climate control, cruise control, and Sony infotainment system with Bluetooth connectivity.
The rear-facing bench seat stows flat into the cargo area floor, and the car is equipped with a cargo-area partition net and a retractable cargo cover.

The leather-wrapped multifunction steering wheel frames a 160-mph speedometer and a tachometer with a 6,400-rpm redline as well as an analog clock and gauges for coolant temperature and fuel level. The digital odometer indicates 101k miles.
The 3.5-liter M272 V6 was factory-rated at 268 horsepower and 258 lb-ft of torque. The battery, drive belt, idler pulley, and air filter were replaced in 2021.
Power is sent to all four wheels through a five-speed automatic transmission.
The Carfax report is free of accidents and other damage.

This 1927 Ford Model T Touring is finished in red with black fenders over black tufted upholstery, and power comes from a 177ci inline-four mated to a two-speed planetary-gear transmission and a Ruckstell rear axle. Features include a 12-volt electrical system, an electric starter, 21″ wire-spoke wheels, a rear-mounted spare, running boards with Ford-branded step plates, glass wind wings, and a black soft top. This final-year Model T is now offered by the selling dealer in Portland, Oregon, with a Washington title.

In the final two years of its 1908-1927 production run, the Model T featured all-steel body construction and styling updates that included a larger hood and revised fenders. Model T production ended in 1927, with 81,181 touring-bodied examples produced for the model year. This example was repainted red with black fenders under previous ownership and features a polished radiator surround, a radiator cap thermostat, running boards with Ford-branded step plates, a split-folding windshield, glass wind wings, a black soft top, a single taillight, and a rear reflector.

Red-painted wire-spoke wheels are mounted with Riverside and Bedford bias-ply tires. A matching spare wheel with a Riverside tire is mounted out back. There are areas of paint loss on the wheels, and the Ford-branded center cap is missing from the right-front wheel. The suspension incorporates solid axles and transverse leaf springs, and braking is handled by a band acting on a drum in the transmission.

The cabin features front and rear bench seats trimmed in black tufted upholstery along with color-matched door panels. A black Ford-branded mat covers the front floors, while black carpeting is fitted out back.

The four-spoke steering wheel sits ahead of column-mounted controls for the throttle and spark advance, while a hand lever and three pedals control the brakes and gear selection. A black skull head handle sits atop the shifter. An ammeter is mounted in the center of the dash. The car is not equipped with an odometer, and mileage is unknown.
The 177ci inline-four is painted blue and features a 12-volt electrical system with an electric starter and an aftermarket air cleaner.
Power is sent to the rear wheels via a two-speed planetary gear transmission and a Ruckstell rear axle.
The car is titled by the VIN pictured on the replacement plate above, MT1490247. The Washington title lists a Classic brand.

This 2010 Mercedes-Benz GL550 remained under the care of a single owner in California up until April 2024, and it has 50k miles. It is powered by a 5.5-liter V8 linked with a seven-speed automatic transmission and a 4MATIC all-wheel-drive system and is finished in Arctic White over Cashmere leather. Equipment includes 21″ AMG five-spoke alloy wheels, Airmatic air suspension, a sunroof, bi-xenon headlights, fog lights, running boards, a receiver hitch, Parktronic parking sensors, heated and ventilated multi-contour front seats, heated second-row seats, a Harman Kardon LOGIC7 sound system, cruise control, tri-zone automatic climate control, Keyless Go, and COMAND infotainment with navigation. This X164 GL550 is now offered in New Jersey by the selling dealer at no reserve with the owner’s manual and a clean California title.

The truck is finished in Arctic White (650) and features bi-xenon headlights with Active Curve Illumination as well as a power sunroof, a power-operated liftgate, a receiver hitch, headlight washers, fog lights, brushed aluminum running boards, power-operated rear quarter windows, LED daytime running lights, Parktronic front and rear parking sensors, and a rear window wiper. The Carfax report notes damage in a June 2019 entry. Paint blemishes are shown up close in the gallery.

The 21″ AMG five-spoke alloy wheels are mounted with Continental CrossContact tires that show date codes from 2022. The truck is equipped with an Airmatic dual-control semi-active air suspension system, and braking is handled by disc brakes at all four corners.

The heated and ventilated multi-contour front seats are trimmed in Cashmere leather, while burl walnut wood accents the dashboard, center console, and door panels. Amenities include driver-seat position memory settings, heated second-row seats, third-row seating, a rearview camera, a Harman Kardon LOGIC7 sound system, cruise control, tri-zone automatic climate control, Keyless Go, Blind Spot Assist, and COMAND infotainment with navigation.

The leather- and wood-rimmed multifunction steering wheel frames a central multifunction display, a 160-mph speedometer, a 7k-rpm tachometer, an analog clock, and a fuel-level gauge. The digital odometer indicates 50k miles. The tire pressure warning light is illuminated.

The 5.5-liter DOHC V8 was factory rated at 382 horsepower and 391 lb-ft of torque. Power is sent to all four wheels through a seven-speed automatic transmission and a 4MATIC all-wheel-drive system. The spark plugs, transmission fluid, and the transmission pan gasket were replaced in April 2019.
The Carfax report shows the aforementioned damage.

This 2010 Tesla Roadster Sport 2.0 was acquired new by the seller and now has 3,200 miles. It features a 53-kilowatt-hour battery pack powering a three-phase AC induction motor paired with a single-speed transmission. The car is finished in Thunder Gray over gray leather, and equipment includes a black removable soft top, 16″ and 17″ forged aluminum wheels, the Electronics Group, heated sport seats, a JVC stereo, cruise control, and air conditioning. This Roadster is now offered with a window sticker, the owner’s manual, a clean Carfax report, and a clean Illinois title in the seller’s name.

The Tesla Roadster was based on the aluminum tub from the contemporary Lotus Elise, with which it shared its windshield and windshield frame. The remainder of the carbon-fiber body panels were unique to the Tesla, and it utilized a 2″ longer wheelbase than the Elise. This example is finished in Thunder Gray and features a black removable soft top, an exterior charging port, an integrated rear spoiler, LED taillights, and carbon-fiber on the roof bow.

The 16″ and 17″ forged aluminum wheels are mounted with 175/55 front and 225/45 rear Yokohama Advan Neova tires. The Roadster Sport was factory equipped with traction control as well as adjustable dampers and anti-roll bars. Stopping power is provided by four-wheel discs with a regenerative braking system.

The cabin features heated sport seats upholstered in two-tone gray leather along with matching door panel inserts and a black dashboard. Appointments include a center-mounted screen, a JVC stereo, cruise control, and air conditioning.
The three-spoke leather-wrapped steering wheel fronts a 160-mph speedometer, a kilowatt usage gauge, and a digital vehicle-range bar. The digital odometer indicates 3,200 miles.

A 53-kilowatt-hour battery pack powers a three-phase, 375-volt AC induction motor featuring a hand-wound stator. Factory-rated output was 288 horsepower and 295 lb-ft of torque in Sport specification. The Power Electronics Module and cooling system were cleaned in May 2024.
Power is delivered to the rear wheels through a Borg-Warner single-speed transmission.
The window sticker shows initial delivery to Tesla Motors of San Carlos, California, and lists factory equipment and a total vehicle cost of $145,145.
The Carfax report is free of accidents or other reported damage.

This 2006 Aston Martin DB9 is powered by a 5.9-liter V12 paired with a six-speed manual transaxle and is finished in Meteorite Silver over Bentley Saddle leather. The car is equipped with a limited-slip differential, 19″ 15-spoke wheels, rear parking sensors, heated power-adjustable front seats, a navigation system, a Linn sound system, cruise control, and automatic climate control. The car has spent time on the East Coast and in the Midwest where the selling dealer principal acquired it as a personal vehicle in 2022, and they have since added approximately 1k of the 20k indicated miles. This DB9 is now offered by the selling dealer with a spare key and fob, a car cover, an owner’s manual, a front tow hook-mounted license plate bracket, service records, a clean Carfax report, and a clean Ohio title.

The DB9 featured a mix of aluminum and composite body panels installed over an extruded aluminum spaceframe. This example is finished in Meteorite Silver and features a Tungsten grille, hood vents, fender vents, rear parking sensors, power-folding mirrors, LED taillights, and dual exhaust outlets. Records indicate that the front bumper was repaired in January 2016, and the selling dealer reports that clear paint protection film covers the body.

The 19″ 15-spoke alloy wheels are mounted with Michelin Pilot Sport 4S tires measuring 235/40 up front and 275/35 out back. Braking is handled by four-wheel slotted and ventilated rotors with black-finished Aston Martin-branded calipers. The rear dampers were replaced in June 2016 and a brake fluid flush was performed in preparation for the sale.

The cabin features heated power-adjustable front seats trimmed in Bentley Saddle leather complemented by mahogany wood trim and black carpets. Amenities include a retractable navigation screen, a CD stereo, a Linn sound system, cruise control, and automatic climate control.

The three-spoke leather-wrapped steering wheel frames a 220-mph speedometer, a reverse-sweep tachometer, and gauges for coolant temperature and fuel level. The digital odometer indicates under 20k miles, approximately 1k of which were added by the selling dealer principal.
The 5.9-liter DOHC V12 was factory rated at 450 horsepower and 420 lb-ft of torque. The engine mounts were replaced in June 2016 and the oil was changed in preparation for the sale.

Power is sent to the rear wheels through a six-speed manual transaxle and a limited-slip differential. Records indicate that the clutch disc, slave cylinder, and pilot bearing were replaced in January 2016 when the car had 9k miles.
The Carfax report is free of accidents or other reported damage.

This 1996 Buick Roadmaster Limited Estate Wagon remained with the original owner until 2021 and now shows 55k miles. The car is finished in Light Driftwood Metallic over beige leather and vinyl and is powered by a 5.7-liter LT1 V8 linked with a four-speed automatic transmission and a limited-slip differential. Equipment includes the Towing Package, 15″ aluminum wheels, woodgrain vinyl bodyside applique, power-adjustable front seats, Twilight Sentinel automatic headlights, a Vista Roof, a rear-facing third-row bench, and automatic climate control. The seller purchased the car in 2024. This Roadmaster Estate is now offered at no reserve with a window sticker, the owner’s manual, service records, a full set of spare tires, additional interior accessories, a clean Carfax report, and a clean Pennsylvania title in the seller’s name.

The car is finished in Light Driftwood Metallic (33) with simulated woodgrain vinyl applique on the bodysides and tailgate. Exterior details include roof rails, Twilight Sentinel automatic headlights, a Vista Roof over the second-row seats, remote keyless entry, body-color side mirrors, a power antenna, bright beltline trim, a vertically slatted grille, a Collector’s Edition hood ornament, pop-out rear quarter windows, a rear wiper, and dual exhaust outlets. The rear glass window lift struts were replaced in May 2024.

The 15″ aluminum wheels are mounted with 225/75 Vercelli Classic 787 whitewall tires that were fitted in June 2024. Braking is provided by power-assisted front discs and rear drums. A removed set of 235/70 General Altimax RT43 tires is included in the sale.

The power-adjustable split-front bench and rear benches are upholstered in beige leather and vinyl, while simulated woodgrain trim accents the color-coordinated dashboard and door panels. Appointments include cruise control, a folding armrest with cupholders, automatic climate control, and a power-operated rear window, side windows, locks, and mirrors. The air conditioning system was serviced in May 2024 and a custom-fabricated dash mat is included in the sale.
The cargo area is accessed via a dual-hinged tailgate and features a fold-down rear-facing bench seat.
The leather-wrapped steering wheel frames a 120-mph speedometer flanked by auxiliary gauges for coolant temperature and fuel level. The six-digit odometer shows 55k miles.

The 5.7-liter LT1 V8 features sequential port fuel injection, and factory rated output was 260 horsepower and 330 lb-ft of torque. Additional equipment includes an engine oil cooler, higher-output radiator fans, and increased air conditioning capacity as specified by the optional Towing Package. A coolant flush was performed and the heater core and thermostat were replaced in November 2019. An oil change was carried out and a replacement air filter was installed in preparation for the sale.
Power is routed to the rear wheels through an electronically controlled four-speed 4L60E automatic transmission and a limited-slip differential.
The window sticker shows equipped options and a Total Vehicle Price of $31,540. Service records are also included in the sale.
The Carfax report is free of accidents or other reported damage.

This 1966 Cadillac Calais hardtop sedan is a gold over gold example that is powered by a 429ci V8 paired with a three-speed automatic transmission and equipped with power steering and brakes, cornering lights, rear fender skirts, and an Edelbrock carburetor as well as a power-adjustable front bench seat, automatic climate control, power windows, and a push-button AM/FM stereo radio. Service in the three years leading up to the selling dealer’s acquisition of the car in May 2024 included replacing the alternator, radiator, timing chain, water pump, valve cover gaskets, and shocks. This Calais has 51k miles and is now offered with the manufacturer’s literature, Protect-O-Plate, and a clean Wisconsin title.

The car left the factory finished in Antique Gold and was repainted under previous ownership. Exterior details include stacked headlights, cornering lights, chrome bumpers, rear fender skirts, and squared-off tail fins with vertical taillight towers. Close-up photos showing a paint chip on the nose, a crack on the left front fender, and a rust bubble on the driver-side rear door along with a ding and several nicks in the chrome tail panel can be viewed in the gallery.

Steel 15″ wheels wearing polished and crested covers are mounted with Hankook Optimo H724 whitewall tires showing 2019 date codes. A full-size spare is located in the trunk. The car is equipped with power steering, and braking is handled by power-assisted finned drums all around. The shocks were replaced under previous ownership.

The cabin features front and rear bench seats trimmed in gold cloth and vinyl upholstery with a color-coordinated dash pad, door panels, and carpeting. The front seat is six-way power-adjustable, and additional amenities include power windows, a remote-adjustable side mirror, a push-button AM/FM stereo radio, and automatic climate control with inoperative air conditioning.

The three-spoke steering wheel fronts a 120-mph horizontal-sweep speedometer, fuel-level and coolant-temperature gauges, and an electric clock. The five-digit mechanical odometer shows 51k miles, 400 of which were added by the selling dealer.

The 429ci V8 was factory rated at 340 horsepower and is equipped with an Edelbrock four-barrel carburetor topped by a chrome open-element air filter. Service since 2021 is said to have included replacing the alternator, radiator, timing chain, water pump, and valve cover gaskets along with changing the oil.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through a Turbo Hydra-Matic three-speed automatic transmission. Corrosion is visible on various components of the underbody.
Decoding the Fisher body tag reveals the following:
The car is accompanied by manufacturer’s literature including an owner’s manual, warranty information, and an accessories brochure as well as its Protect-O-Plate.

This 1950 Vincent Rapide was acquired by the seller in 2015 and a subsequent refurbishment performed by Glenn Bewley of Classic Motorcycle Engineering in Greeneville, Tennessee, was completed in early 2021. Work included overhauling its 998cc OHV V-twin, adjusting the fork damper, cleaning and regreasing the rear frame pivoting assembly and spring boxes, and installing an Amal twin-pull throttle assembly, a Neal Videan V3 clutch, and a Dave Hills center stand. The bike is additionally equipped with a Girdraulic fork, a steering damper, quadruple drum brakes, a stepped two-up seat, a hinged rear fender, and four props, including dual Michael Breeding side stands. This Series C Rapide is now offered with an owner’s manual, a parts catalog, Vincent literature, spare and removed parts, the seller’s refurbishment and service records, marketing materials in which the bike is pictured, and a clean Mississippi title in the seller’s name.

The bike is finished in black over black-painted tubular steel frames, the upper of which does not have a stamped number. The fuel tank was repainted during the refurbishment, and the 24-carat gold pinstriping and Vincent transfers were protectively clear-coated. Additional features include polished stainless-steel fenders, the rear of which is hinged, as well as a pedestrian-slicer number plate, a stepped two-up seat, adjustable rider foot pegs and foot controls, folding passenger foot pegs, and four props consisting of dual Michael Breeding side stands, a rear-wheel stand, and a Dave Hills Tread Down center stand.

Black- and red-center-striped chrome rims measuring 20″ up front and 19″ at the rear are laced to dual drum-brake hubs from a Black Shadow and mounted with Avon Speedmaster MKII front and Safety Mileage MKII rear tires which the seller recommends replacing before riding. Suspension consists of a Girdraulic fork and a triangulated swingarm, both of which are fitted with adjustable Koni dampers.

A flat handlebar equipped with bar-end mirrors, replacement Amal grips, and an Amal twin-pull throttle assembly is clamped ahead of the adjustment knob for a friction plate damper in the steering stem. Instrumentation consists of a Smiths Chronometric 150-mph speedometer from a Black Shadow and a Miller ammeter recessed atop the headlight bucket. The five-digit odometer shows 2,500 miles, approximately 2,300 of which were ridden by the seller. True mileage is unknown.

The 998cc OHV V-twin breathes through a pair of Amal pre-Monobloc carburetors fitted with open velocity stacks as well as a two-into-one exhaust system with down-turned headpipes flowing into a low-mounted Burgess-style muffler. The engine underwent an overhaul at Classic Motorcycle Engineering of Greeneville, Tennessee, that was completed in early 2021 and included:
A detailed invoice for the refurbishment can be viewed in the gallery.
The bike is title using number F10AB12867 stamped on the left engine case.

Power is sent to the rear wheel through a Neal Videan V3 wet/dry clutch and a four-speed transmission that is shifted on the right with a one-up, three-down pattern. The drive chain is equipped with a drip-feed oiler that has been disabled.

This 2007 Saab 9-3 SportCombi remained registered with its original owner in Ontario, Canada through 2023, and it now has 36k kilometers (~22k miles). Powered by a turbocharged 2.0-liter inline-four paired with a six-speed manual transaxle, the car is finished in black over black and gray leather upholstery. It also has 17″ alloy wheels, a sunroof, projector-beam headlights, fog lights, heated power-adjustable front bucket seats, a CD stereo, automatic climate control, and cruise control. Acquired by the selling dealer in 2024, this 9-3 SportCombi is now offered in Canada by the selling dealer with manufacturer’s literature, US and Canadian Carfax reports, and Ontario registration.

The car is finished in black and features a sunroof, front and rear fog lights, and projector-beam halogen headlights with washers. The Carfax reports list an accident reported in October 2022 with another vehicle that resulted in damage to the rear. The selling dealer states that paintwork has been performed on the left-front wheel arch. Paint meter readings are presented in the video gallery below.

Split five-spoke 17″ alloy wheels are mounted with 235/45 Continental ContiProContact tires that show 2007 production codes. The car came equipped from the factory with an Electronic Stability Program (ESP) and four-wheel anti-lock disc brakes. The brake fluid was flushed and an alignment was performed in 2023.

The heated power-adjustable front bucket seats and rear bench are trimmed in black leather with gray accents, and wood veneer trim accents the center console and door panels. Additional interior appointments include a CD stereo, dual-zone automatic climate control, cruise control, a retractable rear cargo area cover, and Night Panel, the latter of which reduces cabin and instrument-panel lighting for nighttime driving.

A multifunction steering wheel frames a 260-km/h speedometer, a 7k-rpm tachometer, and auxiliary gauges for coolant temperature, boost pressure, and fuel level. The digital odometer indicates 36k kilometers (~22k miles).
The turbocharged 2.0-liter inline-four was factory rated at 210 horsepower and 221 lb-ft of torque. The oil was changed and the throttle body was cleaned in November 2023.
Power is sent to the front wheels through a six-speed manual transaxle.
The Carfax report lists the aforementioned accident, and a Canadian Carfax report can be viewed in the gallery.
The car does not have a title and is being sold on its Ontario registration, which serves as the ownership document in Ontario, Canada

This 2013 Fiat 500 Abarth is powered by a turbocharged 1.4-liter inline-four paired with a five-speed manual transaxle and is finished in Bianco over Nero leather upholstery. Equipment includes the Comfort and Convenience Package, black Abarth graphics, a rear spoiler, 17″ forged aluminum wheels, heated front seats, a Beats sound system, and automatic climate control. The selling dealer acquired the car in 2024 and it now has 56k miles. This 500 Abarth is offered in California at no reserve with two keys and a clean South Carolina title.

The Abarth features revised bumper covers and rocker extensions compared to the standard 500. This example is finished in Bianco (PW3) with black Abarth graphics, and exterior equipment includes fog lights, a rear spoiler, Abarth badging, and dual exhaust outlets. The Carfax report notes “minor damage” to the front in a May 2019 entry as well as “minor damage” to the rear in a June 2021 entry. The right rocker panel has a scratch, paint chips are evident on the front end, and the selling dealer notes swirl marks on the rear bumper. Paint meter readings are shown in the gallery below.

The 17″ forged aluminum wheels are mounted with 205/40 Nitto Neo Gen tires. The car is equipped with a sport suspension, and stopping power is provided by ventilated front and solid rear discs. The lower control arms were replaced in April 2021.

The heated front seats are upholstered in Nero leather with red accents and stitching that extends to the instrument binnacle and shifter. Amenities include a Beats sound system, a CD stereo, cruise control, aluminum pedal covers, and automatic climate control. The power mirror switch was replaced in June 2024.

The leather-wrapped multifunction steering wheel fronts a 160-mph speedometer, an inset tachometer with a 6,500-rpm redline, and digital gauges for coolant temperature and fuel level, while a turbo boost gauge with a shift indicator is mounted to the left. The digital odometer shows 56k miles.

The turbocharged 1.4-liter inline-four was factory rated at 160 horsepower and 170 lb-ft of torque when paired with the five-speed manual transaxle. The spark plugs and air filter were replaced in April 2021.
Additional underside photos are presented below. The fuel tank was replaced in August 2018.
The Carfax report lists the aforementioned damage reports.

This 1988 Chrysler Fifth Avenue is finished in Ice Blue over blue leather upholstery and is powered by a 5.2-liter V8 linked to a three-speed automatic transmission. Equipment includes a landau top, chrome bumpers and trim, power-assisted brakes with front discs, and 15″ wheels with wire-style covers as well as air conditioning, a power-adjustable front bench, a cassette stereo, and power windows and locks. Acquired by the selling dealer in June 2024, reportedly from its second owner, this Fifth Avenue is now offered in South Carolina with a clean Carfax report and a clean Virginia title.

The car is finished in Ice Blue with darker-blue double pinstriping. Exterior details include a padded vinyl landau roof, a Pentastar hood ornament and badges, power-adjustable mirrors, a telescoping antenna, and chrome bumpers with black rub strips and overriders.
Steel 15″ wheels with wire-style covers are mounted with 205/75 Venezia Classic 787 thin-whitewall tires. Braking is provided by power-assisted front discs and rear drums.

The 60/40-split front bench features power adjustability and, along with the rear bench, is upholstered in tufted blue leather. The fold-down front-center armrest and the door panels are trimmed to match, and the cabin is further appointed with air conditioning, a Chrysler AM/FM/cassette stereo, woodgrain trim, cruise control, a rear window defroster, power windows and locks, and an overhead console with an ambient temperature gauge and a compass.

The two-spoke steering wheel frames an 85-mph speedometer and gauges for coolant temperature and fuel level. The five-digit odometer shows 30k miles, approximately five of which were added under current ownership.

The 5.2-liter V8 was equipped with a two-barrel carburetor and was factory rated at 140 horsepower and 265 lb-ft of torque. Per the selling dealer, recent work consisted of changing the oil and replacing the belts, hoses, spark plugs, and ignition wires.
Power is sent to the rear wheels via a Torqueflite three-speed automatic transmission.
The Carfax report show no accidents or other damage from the initial July 2021 entry.
listing_details: Ice Blue Paint w/Vinyl Landau Roof

description: This 2012 Land Rover LR4 HSE has remained registered in California from new and is finished in Orkney Gray Metallic over Ebony leather upholstery. Power is provided by a 5.0-liter V8 linked to a six-speed automatic transmission and a dual-range transfer case. Features include 20″ Style 560 alloy wheels, an electronic air suspension, fog lights, running boards, parking sensors, heated power-adjustable front seats, third-row seating, a Harman Kardon sound system, a rearview camera, navigation, cruise control, and dual-zone automatic climate control. The selling dealer acquired the truck in 2015 and has since added approximately 66k of the 116k miles. This LR4 is now offered with the owner’s manual, service records, a clean Carfax report, and a clean California title.
The truck is finished in Orkney Gray Metallic and features fog lights, dual sunroofs, running boards, front and rear parking sensors, tinted windows, a split tailgate, and a rear window wiper.

The 20″ Style 560 alloy wheels wear a black powder-coated finish and are mounted with 255/55 Pirelli Scorpion AS Plus 3 tires. Braking is handled by ventilated discs at each corner, and the truck is equipped with an electronic air suspension, a Terrain Response system, All-Terrain Dynamic Stability Control, Hill Descent Control, and Hill Start Assist. The brake pads and rotors were replaced in May 2023.

The cabin features heated power-adjustable front seats trimmed in Ebony leather, and amenities include third-row seating, Grand Black lacquer trim, a Harman Kardon sound system, a rearview camera, keyless entry, push-button start, navigation, cruise control, and dual-zone automatic climate control. A water leak was repaired in February 2024. The left third-row seat latch is temperamental, and the glovebox door latch finish is worn.

The multifunction steering wheel frames a 145-mph speedometer, a central digital display, and a tachometer. The digital odometer indicates 116k miles, approximately 66k of which were added under current ownership.

The 5.0-liter AJ133 V8 was factory rated at 375 horsepower and 375 lb-ft of torque. The spark plugs were replaced in December 2019, the fuel pump was replaced in July 2022, an oil change was carried out, a coolant leak was prepared, and the spark plugs were replaced in December 2023, and the coolant crossover pipes were replaced in preparation for the sale.
Power is sent to all four wheels through a six-speed automatic transmission and a dual-range transfer case.
The Carfax report is free of accidents or other reported damage.

This 1959 Alfa Romeo Giulietta Sprint was delivered new through Hoffman Motor Car Company in New York, and underwent a multi-year refurbishment between 2010 and 2013. Work involved repainting the body, reupholstering the cabin, and replacing various interior and exterior trim components in addition to rebuilding the twin-cam inline-four with a 1.4-liter displacement kit, installing a five-speed manual transmission, and overhauling the suspension. The car is finished in Chevrolet Mariner Blue over white leather upholstery and is further equipped with a single Weber carburetor, finned front drum brakes, Koni shocks, and 15″ aluminum wheels. Previously listed on BaT in October 2021, this Tipo 750B is now offered by the selling dealer in Arizona with photographs and records from the refurbishment along with a clean Oregon title.

The Bertone-styled Giulietta Sprint was unveiled at the 1954 Turin Motor Show, and this late-production 750-Series example features transitional styling elements including grid-style front grilles as well as larger headlight and taillight lenses. The body left the factory finished in Blu Tornado (319), and it was stripped and repainted in Chevrolet Mariner Blue as part of the aforementioned refurbishment. The right rocker panel, rear valance, and quarter panels were replaced at that time.

The 15″ aluminum wheels wear Campagnolo decals and are mounted with 155-series Pirelli Cinturato tires. Stopping power is provided by four-wheel drum brakes, and the fronts are equipped with finned-aluminum drums. Koni shocks have been installed at all four corners, and other components replaced as part of the prior refurbishment include the shock mounts, tie rod ends, upper ball joints, and wheel bearings along with various bushings and brake components.

The cabin houses rebuilt low-back seats trimmed in white leather as well as color-coordinated door panels and blue carpets. Further details include a dash-mounted rear-view mirror, a lockable glovebox, and lap belts. The dash topper is worn.

The two-spoke steering wheel frames a tachometer with an inset oil-pressure gauge flanked by a 120-mph speedometer and a combination gauge indicating fuel level, oil temperature, and coolant temperature. The five-digit odometer shows just over 900 miles, approximately 100 of which have been added by the selling dealer. The instrumentation was refurbished by Palo Alto Speedometer, and total mileage is unknown.

The twin-cam inline-four was rebuilt and modified to displace 1.4 liters at the time of the refurbishment. It is equipped with Carrillo rods, Euro-spec camshafts, forged pistons, and a single Weber carburetor. A custom-made aluminum radiator has also been installed along with a Bendix fuel pump.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through a five-speed manual transmission that was sourced from a 105-Series coupe.

A collection of photographs from the refurbishment process will accompany the car along with correspondence from Centro Documentazione Alfa Romeo indicating the factory color, identification numbers, and a build date of March 16, 1959.

This 2009 Porsche 911 Carrera S coupe is one of three 911s modified by Akira Nakai of RAUH-Welt Begriff for the selling dealer in September 2023 at the selling dealer’s Saskatoon facility. Finished in Acid Green over black leather, the car is equipped with a widebody kit, a ducktail decklid, an ECUWerks stage two tune, a Fabspeed carbon-fiber air intake, tubular headers, an Armytrix exhaust system, KW V3 coilover suspension, and 19″ three-piece wheels. It is powered by a 3.8-liter flat-six paired with a seven-speed PDK dual-clutch transaxle, and additional features include the Sport Chrono Package Plus, bi-xenon headlights, heated power-adjustable front seats, automatic climate control, and a Bose sound system. The seller acquired the car in 2020 and work in preparation for the sale consisted of changing the oil, flushing the brake fluid, and replacing the battery. This 997.2 C2S coupe has 97k kilometers (~60k miles) and is offered by the selling dealer with a clean Carfax and a clean Saskatchewan registration.

The car left the factory finished in Carrara White and was refinished in Acid-Green with gold hand-painted script on the hood and fuel door during the RWB build. Modifications include a front chin spoiler, black mesh grille, side skirts, and a ducktail decklid. Additional details include body-color headlight washers, bi-xenon headlights, LED taillights, and quad exhaust outlets with polished finishers.

Three-piece 19″ forged wheels with mesh centers and copper-anodized rims are mounted with 225/35 front and 305/30 rear Michelin Pilot Sport 4S tires. The lowered suspension rides on adjustable KW V3 coilovers and the car was factory-equipped with Porsche Stability Management (PSM), an active brake differential (ABD), and Anti-Slip Regulation (ASR).  Braking is handled by red multi-piston Porsche-branded brake calipers fitted over a cross-drilled and ventilated rotor at each corner. The brake fluid was flushed in June 2024.

The heated power-adjustable front seats and individual rear seats are upholstered in black leather. Body-color trim accents the dashboard and center console, and appointments include hand-painted Japanese script on the glovebox door, automatic climate control, Guards Red seat belts, and a CD stereo linked to a Bose sound system.

Body-color bezels adorn the white-dial instrumentation cluster which consists of a central tachometer, a 200-mph speedometer, and gauges for oil temperature, oil pressure, coolant temperature, and fuel level. The Sport Chrono package added a stopwatch atop the dash. The digital odometer indicates 97k kilometers (~60k miles).

The 3.8-liter 9A1 flat-six features direct fuel injection and VarioCam Plus variable valve timing, and modifications include an ECUWerks stage two tune, a Fabspeed carbon-fiber air intake and heat shield, tubular stainless-steel headers, and an Armytrix exhaust system. The catalytic converters have been removed. The oil was changed and the battery was replaced in preparation for the sale.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through a seven-speed PDK dual-clutch transaxle that can be shifted manually or driven in automatic mode.
The Carfax report shows no accidents or other damage and lists history in Pennsylvania and Ohio as well as British Columbia and Saskatchewan, Canada.
The car does not have a title because it is registered in a province that does not issue them. It is being sold on its Saskatchewan registration.

This 1997 Land Rover Defender 90 is a North American-Specification example that spent time in Canada before it was brought to the US in 2019 and acquired by the seller later that year. It is finished in blue over gray cloth upholstery and has a roll cage, a pop-up sunroof, a receiver hitch, and 16″ alloy wheels in addition to air conditioning, power front windows, and an aftermarket stereo and speakers. Power is provided by a 4.0-liter V8 mated to a four-speed automatic transmission and a full-time four-wheel-drive system with a dual-range transfer case. This Defender 90 has 27k miles and is offered with a clean Carfax report and a clean Virginia title in the seller’s name.

The aluminum body is finished in Arles Blue with a white roof and black wheel arch flares. Fitted with a roll cage from the factory, the truck is further equipped with a pop-up sunroof, a receiver hitch, and sliding rear windows. A rear plaque identifies the vehicle as #338 of approximately 2,800 North American-Specification examples for the model year. The turn signal bulbs were replaced in 2021.

The 16″ alloy wheels are mounted with BFGoodrich All-Terrain T/A KO2 tires measuring 265/75. A spare is secured to the rear of the truck. Stopping power is provided by power-assisted discs at all four corners.

The front bucket seats and rear jump seats are trimmed in patterned cloth upholstery with black vinyl sides. Cabin details include an aftermarket stereo and speakers along with air conditioning, a clock, and power front windows.

Instrumentation includes a 120-mph speedometer, a tachometer, and auxiliary gauges for coolant temperature and fuel level. The digital odometer indicates 27k miles, approximately 200 of which were added under current ownership.
The 4.0-liter V8 was factory rated at 182 horsepower and 232 lb-ft of torque. The battery was replaced in 2021 according to the seller.
Power is sent to all four wheels through a four-speed automatic transmission and a full-time four-wheel drive system with a dual-range transfer case.
The Carfax report is free of accidents or other reported damage.

This 2002 Toyota Camry XLE has remained registered in Illinois since new and was acquired by the seller in 2023, and it now has 17k miles. The car is powered by a 3.0-liter V6 paired with a four-speed automatic transaxle and is finished in Desert Sand Mica over Macadamia cloth. A remote start system has been retrofitted, and additional equipment includes 16″ alloy wheels, a power-operated sunroof, power-adjustable front seats, automatic climate control, cruise control, a rear window sunshade, and a JBL CD/Cassette stereo. This Camry is now offered at no reserve with an owner’s manual, an accident-free Carfax report, and a clean Illinois title in the seller’s name.
The car is finished in Desert Sand Mica (4Q2) and features bodyside pinstripes, a power-operated sunroof, halogen headlights, and heated and power-adjustable mirrors.

Silver-finished 16″ alloy wheels are mounted with 215/60 Arizonian Silver Edition tires. The car is equipped with a four-wheel independent suspension system, and stopping power is provided by anti-lock disc brakes at all four corners.

The power-adjustable front bucket seats and rear bench seat are upholstered in Macadamia cloth with patterned inserts. A remote start system has been retrofitted, and appointments include faux woodgrain trim, automatic climate control, Weathertech front floor mats, a rear window sunshade, and a JBL CD/Cassette stereo.

The four-spoke multifunction steering wheel frames a 140-mph speedometer, a tachometer, and auxiliary gauges for coolant temperature, and fuel level. The digital odometer indicates 17k miles, approximately 400 of which have been added under current ownership.
The 3.0-liter V6 features quad camshafts and was factory rated at 192 horsepower. The water pump, camshaft tensioner assembly, and timing belt components were replaced in March 2021.
Power is delivered to the front wheels via a four-speed automatic transaxle. Rust is visible on the underside components, and additional images are viewable in the gallery below.
An owner’s manual and two keys are included in the sale.
The Carfax report lists at least one open recall.

This 1996 Volvo 850 sedan was registered with one owner in California through 2022 and was purchased by the seller March 2024 on BaT. The car is finished in white over beige leather, and it has a cassette stereo and a CD changer. Power comes from a 2.4-liter inline-five paired with a four-speed automatic transaxle. Reported work since 2022 included replacing the timing belt, radiator, wheels, tires, shocks, struts, motor mounts, rear main seal, and front brake pads and rotors. This 850 sedan shows 240k miles and is now offered at no reserve with owner’s manuals, service records, and a clean Colorado title.
Finished in white with black trim, the car was ordered without a sunroof, and it has heated power-adjustable mirrors.

Columba 16″ alloy wheels are wrapped in 205/55 Falken Ziex ZE950 A/S tires mounted since 2022. The car features power-assisted rack-and-pinion steering and four-wheel disc brakes with ABS. The factory suspension included a MacPherson front strut setup with asymmetrically mounted coil springs and forged aluminum lower link arms as well as a Delta-Link semi-independent rear system with coil springs. The struts and shocks were replaced in May 2024, at which time new front brake pads and rotors were installed.

The manually adjustable front seats are trimmed in beige leather, and side-impact airbags are integrated into their outer bolsters. Volvo’s Side Impact Protection System (SIPS), which was introduced on the 850, also utilized reinforced pillars and a honeycomb structure inside the doors.

The cabin has a cassette stereo, which is linked with a CD changer mounted in the trunk. The air conditioning does not work. The six-digit odometer shows 240k miles, approximately 1,500 of which were added under current ownership.

The transverse 2.4-liter inline-five was factory rated at 168 horsepower and 162 lb-ft of torque. The radiator was reportedly replaced under prior ownership, and a sticker in the engine bay indicates that the timing belt and water pump were replaced in March 2023. The rear main seal, torque converter seal, and engine mounts were replaced in May 2024.
Power is routed to the front wheels through a four-speed automatic transaxle.
The Carfax report shows no accidents or damage. A July 2020 entry states that the vehicle was designated as a Gross Polluter by the State of California.

This 1989 Toyota Pickup is a Deluxe example that was purchased new by the seller’s late father. Finished in Light Blue Metallic over blue cloth upholstery, the truck is powered by a 3.0-liter V6 paired with a four-speed automatic transmission and a dual-range transfer case. Equipment includes 15″ split-spoke wheels, power-assisted front disc brakes, manually locking front hubs, a hardshell bed cap, a Pendaliner bedliner, air conditioning, and an Alpine stereo. Acquired by the seller in 2023, this Toyota pickup shows 259k miles and is offered at no reserve with manufacturer’s literature, service records, and a clean Washington title in the seller’s name.

The truck is finished in Light Blue Metallic (8D8) with blue side graphics and a Brahma hard shell bed cap. Additional exterior features include a Pendaliner bedliner, mudguards, halogen headlights, and bright bumpers. A December 2007 entry shows that it was involved in an accident with another motor vehicle, and the following entry states that it was declared a total loss by an insurance company. Close-up photographs of the exterior finish and trim are shown in the gallery below.

This is a relist after the vehicle was previously sold on BaT in May 2024 and the winning bidder failed to follow through with their commitment to purchase. This was not due to any fault with the vehicle. The winner’s participation on BaT has been restricted and their buyer’s fee was not refunded.

Silver 15″ split-spoke wheels are mounted with 235/75 Wild Country Radial XTX tires. The truck is equipped with manually locking front hubs, and braking is handled by power-assisted front discs and rear drums with ABS.
The cabin features a bench seat trimmed in Blue cloth, and equipment includes air conditioning, hand-crank windows, rubber floor mats, and an Alpine CD stereo.
Instrumentation includes a 110-mph speedometer and auxiliary gauges for coolant temperature and fuel level. The six-digit odometer shows 259k miles.

The 3.0-liter 3VZ-E V6 features fuel injection for a factory rating of 150 horsepower and 180 lb-ft of torque. The seller states that the radiator was replaced in 2015, the alternator and battery were replaced in 2018, the drive belts were replaced in 2019, and the valve cover gasket and plenum gasket were replaced in 2020.
Power is sent to the rear or all four wheels through a four-speed automatic transmission and a dual-range transfer case. The transmission fluid was changed in 2019.
The Carfax report shows the aforementioned December 2007 damage and total loss entry. A redacted image of the clean Washington title is presented in the gallery.
listing_details: Light Blue Metallic Paint w/Blue Side Graphics

description: This 1975 Norton Commando 850 Roadster was sold new by General Cycle Sales of Lincoln Park, Michigan, and is said to have remained primarily on display before being acquired by the seller in 2022 with 6 miles on the odometer. It is equipped with an 828cc parallel twin paired with a right-side-shifted four-speed transmission. Features include a black vinyl two-up seat, a front disc brake, 19″ wire-spoke wheels, folding passenger foot pegs, a dual exhaust system, and both center and side stands. This Commando is offered at no reserve with a copy of its MSO, manufacturer’s literature, and a Illinois title in the seller’s name.

The bodywork is finished in black, and features include a black vinyl two-up seat, a chrome-plated headlight shell, a combined stoplight and taillight, folding passenger foot pegs, and both center and side stands.

The 19″ wire-spoke wheels are mounted with period Dunlop Roadmaster tires. Suspension consists of a Roadholder telescopic fork as well as dual shocks mounted to the swingarm. Braking is handled by front and rear discs.
Instrumentation includes a 150-mph Smiths speedometer and a 9k-rpm tachometer. The five-digit odometer shows 6 miles.

The Isolastic rubber-mounted 828cc air-cooled parallel twin is equipped with dual Amal carburetors, an electric starter, and a dual exhaust system. Output was rated at 60 horsepower when new. The bike has not been started or ridden by the seller, and it does not have any fluids.
Power is transferred to the rear wheel through a four-speed transmission with a right-side shifter.

This 1991 Chevrolet Caprice Wagon was initially delivered to Burt Watson Chevrolet of Freeland, Michigan, and is said to have remained with the original owner until August 2023. Thereafter it remained registered in Michigan and was acquired by the selling dealer in May 2024. The car is finished in Medium Gray Metallic over gray cloth upholstery, and power is from a 5.0-liter V8 paired with a four-speed automatic transmission. A two-way tailgate is fitted along with 15″ steel wheels, roof rails with crossbars, air conditioning, cruise control, and a Delco cassette stereo. This Caprice Wagon shows 13k miles and is now offered at no reserve by the selling dealer with a window sticker, an owner’s manual, a clean Carfax report, and a clean Michigan title.

The wagon is finished in Medium Gray Metallic and features bright rocker panel trim, a power antenna, a Chevrolet bowtie hood ornament, a rear window wiper and defroster, and roof rails with crossbars.
Steel 15″ wheels wear wire-style covers and are mounted with 225/75 General Ameritech 4 white-stripe tires. Braking is from antilock front discs and rear drums.

The 55/45-split front bench and second-row bench are upholstered in Gray Custom cloth and are accompanied by woodgrain trim on the dashboard and door panels. Appointments consist of power windows and door locks, cruise control, and a power-adjustable driver’s seat in addition to a Delco AM/FM cassette stereo, pop-out rear side windows, and a rear window defroster.

The two-spoke airbag steering wheel is tilt-adjustable and sits ahead of a horizontal-sweep 85-mph speedometer and gauges for coolant temperature and fuel level. The six-digit odometer shows 13k miles, approximately 100 of which were added by the selling dealer.
The two-way tailgate and lift glass open to reveal the cargo area that has a rear-facing folding bench and a retractable cargo cover.
The 5.0-liter V8 was factory rated at 170 horsepower and 255 lb-ft of torque.
Power is sent to the rear wheels through a four-speed automatic transmission. Corrosion is present on underbody components, photos of which can be viewed in the gallery below.
The window sticker lists factory colors, optional equipment, and a total vehicle price of $21,040. Manufacturer’s literature will also accompany the vehicle.
The Carfax report is free of accidents or other reported damage.

This 1976 Cadillac Seville is said to have been modified by Moloney of Chicago and spent time in Florida before the seller’s acquisition in 2019 and it now shows 97k miles. This brown-over-brown sedan is equipped with power-assisted brakes and 15″ steel wheels as well as automatic climate control, power-adjustable front seats, and power windows and door locks. Power is provided by a fuel-injected 5.7-liter V8 paired with a three-speed automatic transmission, and work performed in 2023 is said to have included converting the air conditioning system to utilize R134a refrigerant and replacing the air conditioning compressor. This Seville is offered with a clean Ohio title in the seller’s name.

An “Executive Stretch” is said to have been carried out by Moloney of Chicago. The body was finished from the factory in Chesterfield Brown, and the seller states the car was repainted in 2016 with custom pinstriping added in 2021. A color-matched padded vinyl roof is fitted along with a power antenna and coach lights. Various trim components were polished and refinished.

The 15″ steel wheels wear full covers with Cadillac center emblems and are wrapped in 215/75 Custom 428 A/S whitewall tires said to have been installed in 2020. A compact spare tire is stored in the trunk. Power-assisted brakes came standard.

The power-adjustable front seats and a rear bench are trimmed in Buckskin leather and complemented by woodgrain trim accents and a Saddle Brown dashboard.  The cabin is appointed with automatic climate control, rear reading lamps, and power windows, mirrors, and door locks. The air conditioning system was converted to utilize R134a refrigerant in 2023, at which time the air conditioning compressor was replaced. The AM/FM radio does not work.
The three-spoke steering wheel is mounted on a tilting and telescoping column and fronts a horizontal-sweep 100-mph speedometer as well as a fuel gauge. The five-digit odometer shows 97k miles.

The 5.7-liter V8 features speed-density port-injected fuel injection and was factory-rated at 180 horsepower and 275 lb-ft of torque, which is sent to the rear wheels through a Turbo Hydra-Matic three-speed automatic transmission. The engine control module (ECM) and the exhaust system were replaced in 2019, according to the seller. The oil was changed in 2023.

This 1928 Dodge Brothers Victory Six sedan is finished in burgundy and black over burgundy cloth upholstery, and power comes from a 208ci inline-six paired with a three-speed manual transmission. Features include four-wheel drum brakes, 19″ wood-spoke wheels, a rear-mounted spare rim, a polished radiator surround, cowl lamps, a rear luggage trunk, running boards, rear-hinged rear doors, and rear cabin flower vases. The car was purchased by the current owner in 2023, and service performed under their ownership included the installation of an electric fuel pump and a 12-volt electrical system conversion. This Victory Six is now offered by the seller on behalf of the current owner at no reserve with a Kentucky title in the owner’s name.

The Victory Six was built for 1928 and the beginning of the 1929 model year and featured bodywork by the Budd Manufacturing Company. This sedan is finished in burgundy with a black roof and fenders as well as white pinstriping. Equipment includes front and rear bumpers, a polished radiator surround with a Dodge Brothers-branded water temperature gauge, cowl lamps, running boards, rear-hinged rear doors, and a luggage trunk.

The wood-spoke wheels wear Dodge Brothers center caps and are mounted with 4.75/5.00–19 bias-ply tires. A spare rim and tire are mounted out back. The Victory Six rode on a 112″ wheelbase and featured front and rear semi-elliptical leaf springs. Braking is handled by drums at all four corners.

The cabin features front and rear benches trimmed in burgundy cloth along with a color-matched headliner, door panels, and carpets. Features include a forward-tilting windshield, a rear window blind, and rear cabin flower vases.

The four-spoke steering wheel fronts a painted steel dashboard and a central instrument panel housing a 60-mph Nippon Seiki speedometer and Stewart-Warner gauges for amperage, fuel level, and oil pressure. The five-digit odometer does not work and is stopped at 52 miles, and approximately 250 miles were added under current ownership. Total mileage is unknown.

The 208ci L-head inline-six features a single Stromberg carburetor and was factory rated at 58 horsepower at 3,000 rpm. A 12-volt electrical system conversion was performed under current ownership, and an electric fuel pump was installed.
Power is sent to the rear wheels via a three-speed manual transmission.
The Kentucky title lists a “not actual mileage” brand.

This 1955 Lancia Aurelia B24S Spider America is one of just 240 Spiders built during a single year of production and is among 181 configured in left-hand drive. Chassis 1044 was delivered new in the US after being completed on May 27, 1955, and is believed to have spent time under the ownership of a Brooklyn collector before being purchased in 1963 by an Illinois owner whose family retained it for 32 years. In 1995 the car was sold via a Los Angeles dealer to an Italian owner who commissioned a three-year refurbishment that included a repaint of the body and Fontana “low-roof” hardtop in pale blue and a re-trim of the interior in dark blue leather. After three years with a Milanese owner, it was purchased by a California owner who commissioned the installation of a Nardi dual-carburetor intake manifold and Borrani wire wheels before the car’s return to the US. The car made an appearance at the 2005 Pebble Beach Concours d’Elegance during the ensuing 14 years in California, after which it returned to Europe and received further mechanical freshening. It was purchased two and a half years ago by its current owner, who has since driven it in the Colorado Grand twice. Powered by a 2,451cc V6 paired with a four-speed manual transaxle, the car also features sliding-pillar front suspension, a De Dion rear axle, and hydraulic drum brakes with inboard rear units. This B24S Spider is now offered at no reserve by the seller on behalf of the current owner with a Lancia Classiche Certificato di Origine, a Centro Storico Fiat certificate, invoices dating back to the 1990s, photos from the 1990s refurbishment, and a clean Montana title in the name of the owner’s LLC.

Unveiled at the 1955 Brussels Motor Show, the B24 Spider variant of the Aurelia featured Pinin Farina-designed coachwork over a shortened version of the chassis utilized by the fourth-series Aurelia GT coupe, with which the Spider also shared its mechanical underpinnings. The Spider was available in both right- and left-hand-drive, or sinistra, configurations and was produced for a single year only before being succeeded by the more conventionally appointed B24 convertible.

Originally finished in Grigio, this example was stripped to bare metal before being repainted in its current shade of Azzurro during the refurbishment performed between the mid-to late-1990s, at which time the Fontana removable hardtop was refinished to match. Styling elements include a panoramic windshield, low-profile doors free of exterior handles, split bumpers, an intake scoop allowing a lower hood line, and a blue convertible top that can be stowed beneath the rear bodywork. The soft top rear window was replaced in 2023.

Borrani wire wheels were trued and balanced during work performed between 2022 and 2023 and are secured by two-eared knock-offs. Michelin X tires measuring 165R400 were mounted during the project. Stopping is handled by hydraulic drum brakes with inboard rear units, and service performed between 2022 and 2023 included replacement of the master cylinder and wheel cylinders as well as turning of the drums.

The cabin was re-trimmed during the 1990s refurbishment and features dark blue leather over buckets seats for two with matching upholstery over the dash edge, kick panels, and lower portions of the door panels. Features include black rubber floor mats, latch-and-link lap belts, door pull straps, a shifter to the right of the center tunnel, storage pockets on each seatback, an open dash cubby, a dash-mounted rearview mirror, and a radio blanking plate.

The wood-rimmed steering wheel sits ahead of Veglia instrumentation including a 180-km/h speedometer, a 6k-rpm tachometer, and a combination gauge monitoring oil pressure and fuel level. The five-digit odometer shows 9k kilometers (~6k miles), approximately 2,700 of which have been added under current ownership. True mileage is unknown.

The 2,451cc V6 is an evolution of the Francesco de Virgilio-designed power plant that made the Aurelia the first V6-powered production car and features a 60° angle between cylinder banks, an aluminum block, aluminum cylinder heads with hemispherical combustion chambers, and pushrod-driven overhead valves. A Nardi intake manifold and air cleaner were added in the early 2000s, allowing induction through twin Weber 40 DCL5 carburetors. Service performed by Fast Cars of Redondo Beach, California, between 2022 and 2023 included the addition of PerTronix electronic ignition as well as rebuilds of the generator and steering box, a valve adjustment, replacement of the fuel pump, and adjustments to the carburetors.

Power is sent to the rear wheels via a rear-mounted four-speed manual transaxle, and work between 2022 and 2023 included replacement of the clutch and throwout bearing. The sliding-pillar independent front suspension incorporates coil springs and adjustable shocks contained in oil around vertical pins on either end of a beam axle, while the rear suspension shares the De Dion axle that was introduced on all fourth-series Aurelias. Suspension work during the last three years included rebuilds of the front shocks and rear leaf springs as well as refinishing of various components. The mufflers were replaced in 2022.
An album containing photographs from the 1990s refurbishment is included in the sale, as are invoices from the 2022-2023 work.
The Lancia Classiche certificate of origin lists the original colors and component numbers as well as completion in May 1955.
listing_details: Twin Weber Carburetors w/ Nardi Intake

description: This 1966 Shelby Cobra is one of approximately 260 street-specification Mark III examples produced and was billed to Shelby American by AC Cars Limited on March 10, 1966, before being invoiced to Hi-Performance Motors in El Segundo, California, on July 7 of the same year. Chassis 3220 spent its first two decades in California, where it was fitted with a 427ci side-oiler V8 circa the 1970s. After moving to England in 1989, the car underwent a refurbishment that included a conversion to semi-competition specification before returning to the US in 1993. It was purchased by its current owner in 2023 and subsequently underwent an additional refurbishment that included a return to its original shade of Guardsman Blue. Among the S/C-style features are fender flares, a hood scoop, side-pipe exhaust, an oil cooler, adjustable Koni coilover shock absorbers, Halibrand pin-drive wheels, an aluminum trunk floor, a 41-gallon fuel tank, and a roll hoop. Additional equipment includes a four-speed manual transmission, four-wheel disc brakes, black leather upholstery, and a Moto-Lita wood-rimmed steering wheel. This semi-competition-style 427 Cobra is now offered on dealer consignment in Thousand Oaks, California, with photos from the refurbishment and a clean Pennsylvania title.

Shelby introduced the 427 variant of the Cobra in competition trim in 1965 as part of an effort to bolster the model’s racing presence by homologating a big-block-powered version of the platform. Revisions to the AC-built chassis necessitated by the heavier powerplants included 5” of width added to the steel ladder frame, which featured main tubes enlarged to 4” in diameter and rode on a coil-spring suspension in lieu of the earlier Cobra variant’s transverse leaf springs. The street-oriented version of the 427 Cobra arrived in late 1965 and was joined by 31 semi-competition, or S/C, cars derived from unsold competition chassis.

This example’s aluminum bodywork was modified in the style of an S/C model under prior ownership and had been repainted red. The body was reportedly stripped to bare metal and repainted in its original shade of Guardsman Blue during the refurbishment that was completed by H&H Performance in DuBois, Pennsylvania, in 2024, at which time the frame is said to have been media-blasted and refinished in black satin. S/C-style details include rear fender flares, a riveted hood with a scoop, bumper jacks, rectangular taillights, side-exit exhaust with four-into-one collectors, a roll hoop, and a Le Mans-type fuel filler cap. The exhaust was recoated in Cerakote in 2024.

Halibrand pin-drive wheels are secured by three-eared knock-offs and wear Goodyear Blue Streak tires measuring 6.00-15 up front and 8.00-15 at the rear. Stopping is handled by four-wheel disc brakes, while steering is via rack and pinion.

The cockpit houses fixed-back bucket seats trimmed in black leather, while color-keyed carpeting covers the floors. S/C-style touches include a dash absent of defrost vents or a glovebox and the deletion of windshield-washing elements. The trunk compartment was fitted with an aluminum floor over a 41-gallon fuel tank, while the batteries were relocated to the area behind the seats.

The wood-rimmed Moto-Lita steering wheel sits ahead of S/C-style Smiths instrumentation including an 8k-rpm tachometer, a reverse-sweep 180-mph speedometer, and gauges monitoring oil temperature, coolant temperature, amperage, fuel pressure, and oil pressure. The five-digit odometer shows 2,300 miles, approximately 200 of which have been added under current ownership.
