The 427ci Ford side-oiler V8 is said to have been installed circa the 1970s in lieu of the car’s original 428ci Police Interceptor engine and is topped by a Holley 780-cfm four-barrel carburetor and a “turkey pan” cold-air box. The lubrication system incorporates an oil cooler.

Power is sent to the rear wheels via a four-speed manual transmission. The double-wishbone independent suspension setup incorporates adjustable Koni coilover shock absorbers at each corner with an anti-roll bar up front.

The car’s entry in the Shelby registry notes the installation of the side-oiler engine early in the car’s life as well as the S/C-style modifications made circa the 1990s. The registry entry also mentions the car’s appearance in 1990s issues of Cars & Parts and Classic & Sportscar magazines.
listing_details: Modified in Style of S/C Variant

description: This 1962 Maserati 3500 GTi was completed in February 1962 before being sold new to an engineer in Milan, Italy, where it was first registered in 1964. Chassis 2078 had made its way to the US by the late 1990s, and in the 2002 was purchased by its current owner, racing driver and author Rich Taylor, who had it fitted with a Chevrolet V8 and a Tremec transmission before using it for participation in various rallies and concours events. A refurbishment performed between 2016 and 2019 included the overhaul and reinstallation of the removed 3,485cc DOHC inline-six with an updated replacement Lucas fuel injection system, an overhaul of the ZF five-speed manual transmission, and a repaint in Rosso Exotico. The car also features a limited-slip differential, four-wheel disc brakes, Borrani disc wheels, independent front suspension, a stainless-steel exhaust system, black leather interior upholstery, power windows, and a push-button AM/FM radio. This Tipo 101 is now offered on dealer consignment in North Salem, New York, with invoices and a clean Florida title describing it as a 1964 model.

The 3500 GT model was first introduced in 1957 and was followed by a revised, fuel-injected GTi variant that was unveiled at the 1960 Geneva Motor Show. The GTi coupe retained its predecessor’s Carrozzeria Touring Superleggera coachwork but integrated styling updates including a slimmer chrome grille surround, rectangular front indicators, front and rear quarter windows, and taillight assemblies with three separate lenses.

Originally finished in Blue Sera, this example received a color change to Rosso Exotico early in its life and was refinished by Davis Auto Body in Copake Falls, New York, during the refurbishment performed between 2016 and 2019. The bumpers were removed in the 2000s, and replacement bumpers were installed during a 2021 refresh by Minisport in Sharon, Connecticut, that also included replacement of the grille.

Silver-painted Borrani disc wheels with alloy rims wear bright replacement hubcaps and are wrapped in 215/70R16 Cooper Evolution Tour tires, while a trunk-mounted spare wears Bridgestone Turanza rubber. Stopping is handled by servo-assisted disc brakes all around, and the brake master cylinder was replaced in 2017.

The cabin was re-trimmed in the 2000s and features black leather over 2+2 seating with matching upholstery over the door panels and upper dash. Additional features include replacement black carpeting, power windows, a lockable glovebox, a Jaeger clock, a cream-color headliner, sun visors, and an AM/FM push-button radio.

The three-spoke steering wheel frames Jaeger instrumentation including a 250-km/h speedometer, an 8k-rpm tachometer, and auxiliary gauges. The five-digit odometer shows 83k kilometers (~52k miles), approximately 50 of which have been added under current ownership.

The 3,485cc DOHC Tipo 101 inline-six features an aluminum block and cylinder head and was overhauled by Restoration and Performance Motorcars in Vermont prior to reinstallation between 2016 and 2017. Work included resurfacing of and welding repairs to the cylinder head, polishing of the crankshaft, reconditioning of the connecting rods, and the installation of replacement pistons, cylinder sleeves, .”010-over main and rod bearings, and valves. The Lucas mechanical fuel injection system was replaced with an updated unit at that time, and a stainless-steel exhaust system was fitted. Additional work included re-coring of the radiator, rebuilds of the starter and generator, and replacement of the oil pump, water pump, and ignition cap and rotor. The fuel pump was replaced in 2021.

Power is sent to the rear wheels via a ZF five-speed manual transmission that was also overhauled during the 2016 project. The clutch was resurfaced at that time, while the flywheel was balanced and the pilot bearing, release bearing, and clutch master cylinder were replaced. Suspension incorporates double wishbones and coil springs up front and a leaf-sprung solid axle at the rear, with tubular shock absorbers and anti-roll bars at both ends. A freshening in 2021 included replacement of the upper and lower front ball joints as well as the installation of replacement exhaust hangers.

The build sheet lists the original colors, specifications, and equipment numbers. The car’s shipping notice can be viewed in the gallery below, as can Maserati Classiche documents including a Certificate of Origin, a Technical and Aesthetic Characteristics sheet, and a Historical information sheet.

This 1960 Bentley S2 is one of 15 examples built with drophead coupe coachwork by H.J. Mulliner and is said to have been constructed for display at the New York International Auto Show in March 1960. Configured in left-hand drive, chassis B75LBR was then delivered new to a Wall Street securities analyst the following month before moving to California with its second owner, with whom it remained until the mid-1990s. The car was purchased by its current owner in 2016 and underwent a freshening in 2021. Finished in white over tan upholstery, the car is powered by a replacement 6.2-liter V8 that breathes through twin SU carburetors and is paired with an automatic transmission. Additional features include power-assisted drum brakes, lever-arm shock absorbers that are adjustable at the rear, power-assisted steering, power windows, air conditioning, and a His Master’s Voice radio. This S2 drophead coupe is now offered on dealer consignment in St. Louis, Missouri, with a factory build sheet, Schoellkopf cards, and Canadian registration.

The S2 was introduced in 1959 as a successor to the S1 and featured power from Rolls-Royce and Bentley’s newly developed V8 powerplant. While most of the 1,863 standard-wheelbase examples of the S2 built wore factory Standard Steel Saloon coachwork, H.J. Mulliner’s two-door, open-roof design appeared on 15 cars, fewer than half of which were configured in left-hand drive such as this example.

Originally finished in Sand, this example wears an older repaint in white with tan coachlining. Features include chrome front and rear bumpers with overriders, Lucas front fog lamps, a fender-mounted antenna, dual side mirrors, and a tan convertible top.

Steel 15” wheels wear chrome covers with body-color rings accented by black pinstripes and are wrapped in 8.20-15 BFGoodrich wide-whitewall tires, as is a spare secured in a compartment under the trunk. Servo-assisted drum brakes feature twin master cylinders handling duplex hydraulic actuation up front and hydromechanical actuation at the rear wheels. The servo is said to have been rebuilt in 2021, while the master cylinders were replaced.

The cabin is trimmed in tan leather over front and rear bench seats, and door panels trimmed in matching upholstery were fabricated during the 2021 refresh. Additional features include color-keyed carpeting, dual-grain wood door caps, fold-out wood trays for the rear passengers, a fold-down rear armrest, front lap belts, power windows, a His Master’s Voice radio, and an aftermarket air-conditioning system with a push-button control panel. The air conditioning is said to have been recharged in 2021. The passenger-side window is said to require assistance going up. The “lower” control knob on the dash does not work, and the heater is not functioning.

The three-spoke steering wheel sits ahead of a dual-grain wood dash that houses Smiths instrumentation including a 120-mph speedometer, a clock, and a combination gauge monitoring oil pressure, amperage, coolant temperature, and fuel level. The five-digit odometer shows 43k miles, approximately 20 of which have been added by the selling dealer.

The replacement 6.2-liter V8 features an aluminum block with cast-iron cylinder liners, aluminum pistons, aluminum cylinder heads with overhead valves, and twin SU carburetors. The fuel pump is said to have been replaced in 2021.

Power is sent to the rear wheels via a column-shifted four-speed automatic transmission. The independent front suspension incorporates coil springs and lever-arm shock absorbers, while the leaf-spring rear axle is equipped with lever-arm shocks that can be adjusted electrically via a switch on the steering column. A stainless-steel exhaust system was reportedly installed during the 2021 refresh.
The factory build sheet lists the H.J. Mulliner coachwork as well as the original colors and equipment.

The vehicle is being sold on its Ontario registration, which serves as the ownership document in Ontario, Canada. The sale does not include a title. It has been imported into the US, and the selling dealer will assist any US-based buyer in obtaining a US title.

This 1912 Harley-Davidson X8E was acquired by the selling dealer in 1994 and a subsequent refurbishment is said to have included an overhaul of its 61ci F-head V-twin by the late Mike Parti in addition to sheet metal fabrication and repairs by Jerry DeMille. The bike was refinished in gray with blue, red, and gold stripes and features a Schebler carburetor, a two-into-one exhaust system, and a “town and country” muffler as well as a single-speed transmission, a rear-hub clutch, brown leather Troxel seats, an Old Sol carbide gas headlight, 28″ wire-spoke wheels, a Sager Cushion leading-link fork, a coaster brake, and a rear wheel stand. This “Silent Gray Fellow” is now offered in California for off-road or display purposes only with a 1912 Saskatchewan, Canada, license plate and a bill of sale.

The bike was finished in gray with blue, red, and gold stripes subsequent to sheet metal fabrication and repairs that were performed by Jerry DeMille during the refurbishment. Brown leather Troxel seats consist of a “Ful-Floeting” post-sprung solo saddle and a double-sprung passenger pillion. Additional equipment includes a Hawthorne Old Sol carbide gas generator and illuminator assembly, partially skirted fenders, a front fender mud flap, fixed passenger foot pegs, and a rear wheel stand.

Wire-spoke wheels with gray-painted and red-striped rims are mounted with white 2×28″ Coker Classic button-tread tires that display sidewall cracks. A Sager Cushion leading-link fork with internal springs comprises the bike’s only suspension. A bicycle-style coaster brake provides stopping power.

The pullback handlebar features through-the-bar cable routing for a twist-grip spark-advance on the left and a twist-grip throttle on the right, and an A.W. Rosen pocket watch is mounted on a clamp attached to the handlebar. Leather covers are fitted to the control cables where they exit the handlebar and descend past the steering stem.

Instrumentation consists of an 80-mph Corbin-Brown speedometer that is mounted atop the fuel tank and driven by a “road gear” affixed to the rear sprocket. The five-digit odometer shows one mile, and true mileage is unknown.

The 61ci F-head V-twin is pedal-started and features features inlet–over–exhaust design as well as a total-loss oiling system, a Schebler carburetor, a Bosch magneto ignition, and two-into-one exhaust pipes flowing into a “town and country” muffler with an adjustable outlet. The engine was overhauled by the late Mike Parti during the refurbishment, and the selling dealer states that it has not been started under current ownership.

The bike features a single-speed transmission and a free-wheeling rear-hub clutch operated by a hand lever on the left. The pedal-start chain on the right is retained, while the chain for the final drive on the left has been removed.
The bike does not have a title or registration. It is being sold on a bill of sale only.
listing_details: Gray Paint w/Blue, Red & Gold Stripes
